PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAJOVIC

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 111 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishioners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenent on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Education in Schools
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the film series produced by Film Australia in conjunction with the Family Planning Association for use in Australian schools ''Let's Talk About It'' is regarded in some Australian States as suitable only for in-service work with experienced teachers;
That its companion series ''Growing Up'' presents a one-sided advocacy of behaviour which is morally controversial;
That the films demonstrate serious deficiencies on educational as well as moral grounds.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That action be taken to ensure that these films be withdrawn from use in Australian schools;
That no more funding be made available to Film Australia for production of sex- education films in conjunction with the Family Planning Association;
That an examination of the activities of the Family Planning Association in health and human relations studies in Australian schools be undertaken at an early date.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VANUATU: USE OF PORTS BY SOVIET WARSHIPS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, refers to a matter that has rightly been the concern of Australians for more than 100 years. In particular, I refer to statements allegedly made this week by the Prime Minister of Vanuatu, Father Walter Lini, concerning the availability of Vanuatu's ports to the Soviet Navy. Are these allegations incorrect or unconfirmed? Has there been some misunderstanding or misreporting? What steps has the Government of Australia taken to reinforce the stable and long-standing situation whereby the co-operative defence and other arrangements between the countries of the South Pacific, including Australia, exclude any such Soviet military intrusions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see an article in this morning's Australian in connection with this matter. I have to say that we have been unable to confirm whether these remarks can be properly attributed to Father Lini, the Prime Minister of Vanuatu. Therefore, I am unable to confirm the accuracy of the report. Nevertheless, I can say that in recent times, and in times past, the Australian Government has made quite clear its position in relation to the matter of Soviet power and its presence in the South Pacific. That is to the effect that we believe Soviet naval power in this area would be a cause of, and a force for, destabilisation in an otherwise peaceful zone. For that reason the situation mentioned by the honourable senator should be reinforced at this time. I will endeavour to obtain confirmation as to whether, in fact, the alleged remarks can be correctly attributed to Father Lini.

Ltd, will not be granted the additional protection it requires and that the company will be forced to retrench 400 workers immediately after the State elections?
—Senator, before the Minister answers, I suggest that you have posed some hypothetical questions within the general question addressed to the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

If one looks at the decisions made on tariffs over the last couple of years and, in particular, those made with respect to the textile, clothing and footwear industries and the motor vehicle industry, one sees that to suggest that there is some carte- blanche for free trade, or a lack of interest in looking after Australian industry, would be very remote from the fact.
—More's the pity.

—I note the interjection by Senator Withers. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LOGGING OF NEW SOUTH WALES RAINFOREST

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Does the Government agree with a recent statement by the Duke of Edinburgh that the rapid rate of disappearance of tropical forest from the world is nothing short of catastrophic? I also ask the Minister whether he has noticed reported statements today by a Minister of the New South Wales Labor Government, Mr Don Day, and Mr Barrie Unsworth of the New South Wales Labor Council urging the continued logging of the now scarce resources of rainforest on public land in New South Wales. In view of widespread opposition by the citizens of New South Wales to continued rainforest logging on land owned by the citizens of New South Wales, I ask the Minister whether he will seek to ensure that the Government will exert whatever influence it can on the New South Wales Government to ensure that virgin rainforest, especially that in the Washpool region, is preserved in its natural state for the benefit of future generations. I ask that the Government also encourage reorganisation of the timber industry through the use of alternative timber resources and reafforestation so that no jobs will be lost as a result of the cessation of rainforest exploitation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of expressions of concern from many quarters about the loss of rainforest and wilderness areas. I am not immediately aware of what the Duke of Edinburgh said although I have seen the newspaper reports to which Senator Mason referred and which appear in today's Press. Many of the matters which were contained in those reports were very much State matters- matters for decision by State governments not only within their constitutional responsibilities but also quite definitely within their administrative responsibilities. If there were a Commonwealth interest-I doubt that there is-I think it would have to be dealt with through the Department of Primary Industry rather than through the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. Of course, it was as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment that I was asked this question by Senator Mason. I recall that when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I had the opportunity of visiting the Aboriginal community at Baryulgil, now Malabugilmah village. That community has an interest in Collum Collum station, which is on the Washpool. I had a chance to look at some of that country and can confirm the beauty and uniqueness of some of that forest. I must say to the honourable senator that much as I would like to respond more positively I do think these are matters which should properly be addressed to the Labor Government of New South Wales. These matters are within the Government's responsibility and it will have to take the decisions on them.

—The Leader of the Government in the Senate will be aware of a statement by the Opposition's spokesman on transport alleging gross extravagance by Ministers of the Fraser Government on overseas travel. Can the Leader tell the Senate how the number of overseas visits taken each year by Ministers of the Fraser Government compares with those of Ministers of the Whitlam Government?
—Are you able to answer that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button will be gratified to know that I can. What is more, I will show that the travelling by Ministers of the Fraser Government over their period in office has been modest compared with that of others.
—Tell us about the Prime Minister.

—With the aid of Senator Button, I will tell the Senate about the Prime Minister too. The need for overseas visits continues to be examined carefully and only visits regarded as essential are approved. The annual number of visits by Ministers of this Government remains lower than that for the previous Labor Government. Up to 19 October 1982 Ministers of this Government made an average of 39 visits annually. Ministers of the Labor Government made an average of 43 visits annually. Since 1976-six years ago-the Prime Minister has made--
—Tell us about the tourist Prime Minister.

—I am now telling the Senate about the Prime Minister. Honourable senators will be gratified to know that Mr Whitlam's long term study of ancient ruins in Greece far outweighed the trips of others. Since 1976 the Prime Minister has made 22 overseas visits other than to Papua New Guinea, including his recent visit to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in Fiji. The total number of visits undertaken by Prime Ministers Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Whitlam, covering a period of 10 years, was 26. Mr Holt made six, Sir John Gorton made seven and Sir William McMahon made two. Mr Whitlam made eleven in his three years as Prime Minister. Mr Whitlam, in his three years in office, was absent for an average of 52 days a year while the present Prime Minister has been absent for an average of only 32 days. Let me repeat that for the joy of those concerned: Mr Whitlam, in his three years in office, was absent for an average of 52 days a year while the present Prime Minister has been absent for an average of only 32 days. So the record of this Government is one of modesty, efficiency and restraint compared with that of others.

—I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. It follows a petition presented in the Senate today by Senator Mason which suggests that the Government has done little to promote the use of solar energy or to conserve fossil fuels. I believe the position to be otherwise. Will the Minister give me details of some of the actions taken by the Government in these two areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted the terms of the petition presented today and, in fact, asked to have a look at a copy. Part of the petition presented stated that the Government should legislate to remove sales tax from solar water heaters. Of course that was done some three years ago, in June 1979. The Government is very keen indeed to encourage the use of renewable energy, particularly solar energy. So, the appliances are exempt from sales tax. Taxation concessions have been introduced to encourage commercial and industrial users to convert from oil and liquefied petroleum gas to other fuels, including solar energy. But I think the most important thing is that a total of almost $7. 9m has been allocated on 124 projects relating to solar energy since the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council program was established in 1978. We are now seeing successful technology emerging from this research resulting in collector technology, the heating and cooling of buildings and, of course, the key area of photovoltaic cells. Australia is also participating in the International Energy Agency program on solar collector technology and has co-operative solar research projects with Japan and India. Indeed, we are taking a front running position in solar energy research.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Tate proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to devise a national policy in order to provide adequate housing at a manageable cost for all Australians.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party presents to the Senate this matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to devise a national policy in order to provide adequate housing at a manageable cost for all Australians.

It raises this matter not merely as a question of shelter for Australians, although for an increasing number of them-one thinks of the homeless and the caravan dwellers-that is indeed their basic predicament, but also as a question of fairness and justice is involved that makes it a matter of national concern that there be a fair deal for those Australians aspiring to decent, affordable housing. That fair deal ought to be guaranteed by coherent national policies devised by the Australian Government. At the moment that is certainly not the case. On the contrary, rather than a fair deal for all Australians in regard to housing, we see a widening of the gap between the rich and the poor and, indeed, between the rich and the middle income earners.

What sort of society is it when the affluent can pay $6m for a waterfront home in Sydney, saving another $1m for decorating, while millions of other Australians live in caravan parks, in the dwindling number of public sector houses, in the insecurity of private leases with high rents or in private houses which are becoming distressingly impossible to finance? Surely there is a need for a national policy. This is not the view just of the Australian Labor Party; it is the view of professionals within the industry itself. The Director of the Australian Institute of Urban Studies, Mr Leo Hawkins, was reported as saying on 29 September:
What governments should be doing is looking to a national housing policy. We have the only national government without a housing department as such.

Indeed, it is the view of the churches that the crisis is becoming such that a more comprehensive, more vigorous and more robust approach by the national Government is required. In the Australian of 27 September the headline was ' Churches lash Government over housing'. On that weekend in late September all the Australain churches highlighted for the first time, as a priority requiring urgent attention by their congregations, the crisis in the housing industry and the provision of housing in Australia. No non-governmental organisations would be more in touch with the needs of people and with as wide a cross-section of the community than the churches. They see it as a matter of national priority. The Government does not.

The Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace issued a report on 6 September entitled 'House and Home'. I commend it to all those who want a clear analysis of the housing situation in Australia and a tough-minded, compassionate approach to the suggesting of solutions. I suggest that they read this report by the Catholic Commission. Amongst other things, the report states:
There is no national housing policy upon which all governments agree.
The report continues:
The Federal Government has a particular responsibility as it controls most government resources and has powers over the economy and the financial system.

Yet, in the opinion of the Catholic Commission, the Federal Government has been unwilling to accept this responsibility. The abolition of the Federal Department of Housing and Construction in May 1982 demonstrated this unwillingness quite clearly. That is a shocking thing. When I arrived here on Budget day this year I looked at the ministerial directory on my desk and thumbed through it in vain to find who was to be the Minister in this Government designated to take responsibility for the provision of adequate afford- able housing for all Australians. That office has been abolished by Mr Fraser and there is nobody within the Government assuming that ultimate responsibility. I say to the Senate and to the people of Australia that the Labor Party, when it comes into government, will establish a department of urban and regional affairs responsible for housing and related social amenities. It will liaise with other departments. It will act in co-operative consultation with State and Territory governments and local government in order to ensure that we have the fullest possible provision of housing at a manageable cost to all Australians. The Labor government will designate a Minister to take responsibility for this most important sector of our society, fulfilling social needs as it does and, of course, generating tremendous employment.

When we think of housing for Australians we tend to think of home ownership-the vanishing dream of so many Australians. I will come to that shortly. But there are other aspects of the housing of Australians which it is necessary to consider. For example, one Australian in every five depends on the private rental sector for housing. That is some 20 per cent of Australians-a very high figure. Some depend on private rental housing from choice-for the freedom it gives them in choice of address and movement-but for most in the private rental sector there is no alternative. As public housing stagnates due to the failure of this Government to provide adequate funds to the States and as home ownership becomes harder to achieve, more and more Australians are trapped in that private rental sector in which rising rents and diminishing real incomes make it impossible for them to save the deposit which will enable them to escape. In addition, there is all the stress caused by the uncertainty of being dependent upon the whim of a private landlord.

Let us look at the stress situations which can emerge. Once more, I turn to the report of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace. One finds outlined in that report some graphic examples of the situations which can emerge and which will be known to all honourable senators and those who are listening. For example, a letter to the editor of the Courier-Mail in Brisbane on 10 March this year states, among other things:
Recently, a block of flats, occupied mostly by old age pensioners, was bought by a group of young men, who promptly raised the rent three times in as many months.
The tenants were told that if they didn't pay up someone else would, and if they didn't like it they could get out.

That is happening time and again in Australia. The inadequacy of the private rental sector to provide shelter at reasonable cost to many Australians is largely associated also with the changing character of inner city areas. For example, one finds in the Sydney district of Waverley a tremendous reorganisation of the housing sector within that district such that, between 1974 and 1981, 90 of Waverley's 237 boarding houses were demolished, displacing 1,000 boarders. Many of them were poor, aged, disabled, ex-prisoners, young people or unemployed people. This was all in favour of the strata unit development with its attendant high costs.

The Labor Party will promote vigorously a higher level of security for private renters through initiatives to expand rental accommodation and through income assistance to renters. There must be an extension of the supplementary assistance to a wider range of social security and adult unemployment benefit recipients. This will be supplementary to those initiatives already taken by the Government. They need to be extended. This will be the subject of a carefully costed statement shortly by Mr Uren of the other place. But what is needed in the private rental sector is a breakthrough concept-a new initiative within Australia. This can be achieved only by a national government taking the lead with clearly perceived social goals.

The Labor Party believes that the Commonwealth, the States and non-profit community organisations could pool their funds to provide for a mix of public and private sector funds to provide for the expansion of low cost rental accommodation. This would include the construction, acquisition and rehabilitation of boarding houses, home units, flats, et cetera. This sort of initiative, using community housing trusts as the vehicle, will help to enable those presently in this sector to acquire equity, through co-operative effort, in the rental accommodation they need. It is a very sensible use of public funds in conjunction with those of non-profit community organisations. Of course, what is also required is an upgrading of the provision of public housing; not welfare housing, as it is sometimes called by Sir Phillip Lynch in his dismissal of the churches concerned in September-welfare housing, with all its overtones of patronising the poor. We are talking about public housing. Funds need to be allocated to this sector in a way which remedies the neglect of the sector over the past four or five years by the present Government.

Applications to rent public housing were up by 15 per cent last year whereas the finance given to the States for that sector was only enough to build about half of what was built some seven or eight years ago. Canon Peter Hollingworth of the Brotherhood of St Laurence stated in a letter to the editor of the Australian some two weeks ago in relation to public housing:

In response to a belated recognition of the crisis brought about by its policies, the Federal Government has increased its direct funding for public housing by $71m. But the accumulated important shortages of those years-
He is referring to the previous years of this Administration-
require a substantially greater federal contribution.

Labor agrees with that and sees the only way of tackling public housing neglect as the instituting of a 10-year program to double the proportion of dwellings held in a variety of public tenures. We grant that this will need the provision of substantial base levels of national funding-some $500m a year-and, of course, a guaranteed real continuity of that funding, but the wasting away of public housing which has occurred in recent years is a disgrace to our nation. I have quoted Canon Peter Hollingworth. There would be few more respected figures tested in the fires of actual experience in attempting to deal with the problems of those who are required to seek public housing for their shelter, and he advocates that course. The Labor Party believes it is essential to undertake that course also.

As to home ownership, it is quite clear that the Australian dream of owning a home is vanishing under twin pressures-a pincer movement. There is a frightening escalation in interest rates, which is within the control of this Government. It controls interest rates in the home lending sector. On the other hand there is a reduction in the real incomes available to those paying off their home loans, whether it be by reduction of overtime or even reduction of the full five-day working week. When incomes are curtailed the money that goes into mortgage repayments becomes a tremendous percentage of the disposable income of the household. Of course, for those who find themselves without employment and therefore without income to sustain their repayments the situation is catastrophic.

A couple of related measures can and will be taken by an incoming Labor government to try to remedy the situation of home buyers seeking loans and seeking to raise deposits. The problems are not only in the maintenance of repayments when there is a regime of high interest rates sustained by this Government's policies and exacerbated every day as the philosophy of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System takes hold amongst Government members, but also in the escalating cost of blocks of land within the Australian urban environment. A headline in the Weekend Australian of mid-September reads: 'Land shortage threat adds to home buyers woes'. It is a fact, as outlined in the newspaper report, that serious land shortages are threatening to develop, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland, and even in the Australian Capital Territory, which will add many thousands of dollars to the deposit required in order even to get a house off the ground or, indeed, to buy into a block of units built on this extremely expensive land.

The ideal would be to have some three-years stock of land ready for use in housing development. But for developers in a context of high interest rates it is increasingly uneconomic to hold stocks at those levels. Therefore it requires something other than market forces to remedy this situation, a situation which the Labor Party believes can be met in part by establishing land commissions and urban land councils with three-year stocks of land for residential development in our Australian urban areas. Of course, we would also encourage more cost- effective and uniform land subdivision methods.

No doubt in the course of the afternoon one will hear remarks by Government defenders about the Budget, the March package and the impact they have had on restoring the fortunes of the housing sector. In the limited time available to me I will not have an opportunity to develop a counter argument fully. but I will deal with the Budget first. The Government announced a series of measures which no doubt will have some ameliorative effect. But the linchpin, the key to getting more money into the housing sector, contained in that Budget was the undertaking by the Government to seek from the Reserve Bank of Australia some $ 300m to release into lending for housing. For two months the Reserve Bank has refused to make that money available to the housing sector. For two months it has defied the Government and it continues to frustrate that key proposal in the Government's Budget strategy. Of course, the Government was promising more than it could guarantee to deliver but it will come as no surprise to Australians that this Government is in the business of making rash promises. But the fact is that the failure to come up with this $300m some two months after the Budget indication that the money would be made available has created yet more uncertainty in the funding of Australians' housing needs.

There is no doubt that the March package was greeted with some ecstasy by the Housing Industry Association. Mr Kirkby-Jones, in a Press release for the Housing Industry Association on 18 March, stated that the housing policy initiatives would dramatically increase home ownership and be of immeasurable assistance to the industry. In the months that have elapsed some measurement has taken place. One finds in an August statement of Mr Kirkby-Jones on behalf of the Housing Industry Association a cry of pain, even taking into account the improved deposit assistance scheme and other measures undertaken in the March package. He stated:
From a peak of 149,160 new dwelling commencements in 1980/81 it is estimated that home building activity slumped to below 130,000 commencements in 1981/82.
He expected 117,000 commencements in 1982-83. He concluded:
Thus, over a two year period-
Due to the policies of this Government, which is my interpolation, although that is the only context in which those remarks can be put-
new dwelling investment will have fallen by about $1.25 billion in real terms;
more than 40,000 jobs will have been lost.

That is, lost to the housing industry. The March package was condemned as a failure by the Housing Industry Association. The Budget strategy is non- operative in its key factor. The Labor Party listens to that cry of anguish from the Housing Industry Association. It listens to the despair of many millions of Australians, whether they be the homeless seeking basic shelter, the caravan dwellers in distressing situations-which will be outlined by my colleague Senator Jones-the public and private renters facing inadequate stocks of rental accommodation and escalating rents or the home buyers of Australia who are unable to finance the fulfilment of the very legitimate and, until the last five or six years of the Fraser Government, the very ordinary expectation that a home was within reach of a working life of repayments.

The incoming Federal Labor Government will be as vigorous as has been the Victorian State Labor Government in addressing these problems. But we will be even more effective because we will accept the national responsibility for meeting this basic social need and will generate employment with all the consequent good effects throughout the Australian economy. This will always be in co-operative consultation with other tiers of government and the housing industry. But it will be a leadership role which provide greater security for renters, restore confidence amongst home buyers, promote stability in the housing industry and fulfil our obligations as a national government to meet this social need in a fair and just way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't Senator Tate mention that?

—It is better, Senator Martyr, to ignore unpleasant facts which fly in the face of the proposition that one is trying to assert. Let us look at the figures for home ownership in Australia. In 1947 a little over 53 per cent of households owned their homes or were purchasing their own homes. SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at any sort of international comparison, it is immediately apparent that Australia has achieved and continues to maintain levels of home ownership which would be the envy of almost any country. We are told that Labor will have a new housing department, and whilst there may not be a lot more houses we can be quite sure that there will be lots more public servants employed to worry about the problem that we are concerned about. It would be interesting to hear Senator Tate give a more detailed exposition of how the Labor Party's control of interest rates would achieve satisfactory housing policies.

The March housing package, which Senator Tate correctly predicted would be referred to in this debate, tackled a number of the problems which faced Australians seeking to buy and to maintain the ownership of their homes during this year. —I certainly approve of that. I approve of anything that will improve the situation which prevails today. In this country between 100,000 and 300,000 people are without shelter. The estimates of the agencies which are trying to house those people vary. Let us give consideration to those 100,000 to 300,000 people who have no form of shelter.
—They all have a right to a home.

—Surely the honourable senator does not think that these people should not be housed. Surely he does not think that there should not be some requirement of government to have some responsibility for those people. Let us look at what the Government has done in relation to pensioners, single income families, the unemployed, young married people and people living in rental accommodation. Some pensioners in Queensland who live in rental accommodation are being charged in the vicinity of $100 to $120 a week by landlords. That places them in a difficult situation. To alleviate this problem two or three pensioners live in the same establishment. The Department of Social Security then puts pressure on them by claiming that a male is living with a female as man and wife and they are not entitled to the benefits which are paid by the Commonwealth. We have forced those people into a situation where they cannot pay the rent. Even the extra $5 or $8 a week which is to be paid to help them to pay the rent will not go anywhere near the amount which they are being charged within the metropolitan area of Brisbane. I believe the Government and the Minister need to have a very close look at what is happening within the Department of Social Security.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the situation at Gladstone where people are living in caravans. A non -political report-it was composed by members of the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party-which was brought down in the Senate pointed out very clearly the problems that exist in a fast developing area such as Gladstone and the problems facing people who cannot gain housing and have to live in caravans and in allotments. The report pointed out that there were no facilities for children and transport facilities were pushed to the limits and could not handle the number of people living in the area. I notice that Senator Haines has a copy of House and Home. A reference was made to caravans in House and Home. I will not read the article but I will draw the attention of the Senate to an advertisement which points out very clearly what is happening to housing in Australia. The advertisement states:
CARAVAN PARK
Sydney
One Year Old.
Modern 108 Sites Fully Developed with Approval for Further 325. Currently Showing 90% Occupancy. All Long-Term Occupants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I discuss the matter of public importance which is before us today, I point out that the report the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry produced was a pre-Budget report and was based on figures issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics that have been proven to be wrong and should have been higher than they were.
—It took into consideration the Government's initiative of 18 March.

—It might have been taken into consideration, but things have changed somewhat since then. In relation to the housing situation in this country, I believe things are now on the improve. With regard to what I might call ordinary housing, it seems that the low was reached in April and things are now beginning to improve. Just yesterday it was announced that the banks had approved housing loans totalling $328m during August. At the same time last year the amount was somewhat lower. In July the figure was $307m. My feeling is that every person should have a house in which to live and in which he has either a share or can contribute towards. All young persons, particularly those facing marriage, have the right to expect that at some stage in their lives-not too far down the track-they will be able to organise the owning of a house of some form in this country. When there are two wage earners in a family the prospect of owning a home, of buying a home, is not too bad at all. Some couples have a very large combined income. Provided they manage their money in a sensible way they can save significantly and purchase a home without too much trouble. I acknowledge that with the interest rates on housing loans being at their present levels the repayments can be quite high. I am pleased to see that so many people have such confidence in the future of this country that they are prepared, even with high interest rates, to plan and start building a home.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a shortage of houses in some areas. I believe there always will be, particularly for people who are in serious need. Three groups which immediately come to mind are one-parent families, young people who for one reason or another cannot live with their parents, and older folk. As other speakers have said, this Government has done a great deal to help those in need. While there is an increase in population there will be a constant need for houses to be built. Any member or senator who leaves Canberra-I believe Canberra is well served with houses-and goes back to his or her State and finds no housing matter placed before him must live in a very lucky area indeed. I believe there will always be a shortage of housing. It is a problem which has been with us for a long time. The situation concerning the number of people who own their own homes is much better now than it was following the war. During a lot of that time a Liberal- Country Party Government has been in power in Canberra.

That is something which we have to remember. This Government wants people to own their own home. It wants the efforts and energies of people to be channelled into building, buying and investing in their own home. The Government regards housing as an important area. Those who heard the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) speak a little while ago will recognise that. I do not believe that is true of the Opposition. The Opposition would like to see the Government own and interfere to a great extent in the area of housing. The Opposition does not want little capitalists. I believe we would have a much worse housing situation if Labor ever gets control of the treasury bench. In relation to housing I worry only about those in need. Those people who want a very large house do not receive my sympathy at all. People who think that by changing the government they will magically get another house should remember what occurred when the previous Labor Government was in power. We must remember what it did to the housing industry as it tried to restructure society, as it used to call it. If those people remember that I know where their vote will go in the next election.

This Government has not been sitting still. It recognises that the provision of houses, particularly for the needy, has to be a real priority and it has provided many benefits for people, particularly those who are having to pay high interest rates. Many people will benefit from the new tax reductions which will come in soon. Just yesterday the Government lowered the interest rate on Australian Savings Bonds, which I believe will lead to the removal of an aberration, a distortion, in the flow of funds in the monetary system. It will allow more money to flow into the building societies and savings banks.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —When you throw a stone into a mob of dogs a few of them will yelp. The Government's action will eventually lead to a reduction in home loan interest rates. Probably, if such a drop were implemented now, it would be a little premature but it will come, and come quickly, if the people of Australia leave this Government in office after the next elections which, as honourable senators may gather from my remarks, I expect to take place fairly soon.
—Will it be 4 December or 11 December?

—I think 11 December. As today's Australian says, the latest bond move is the kindest cut of all. It is kind because it will enable some people, as interest rates gradually come down, to obtain houses. According to the article, some of the banks have said that the drop of 1 per cent in the bond rate, to 13.75 per cent, is not quite enough to stop people investing in the bonds. That has yet to be seen. When there are worries about the economy people naturally tend to play it safe and Australian Savings Bonds are a very secure and good investment.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that all honourable senators support actively the concept of adequate housing being available for all people of all ages. I do not believe that there will be any argument about that, but one does not get more housing by having too much government interference, particularly in regard to what we might call ordinary housing. One does not assist the situation by artificially forcing interest rates down. If that happens the money supply for housing is reduced and fewer people can obtain money to build a home.

Some young people are so fortunate as to be in a position to be helped by their parents to build a house. Some older folk are so fortunate as to find accommodation with their children. Others are able to look after themselves in a unit or small house, but there is an ever-growing number of older people who, for a number of reasons, cannot live with their children or provide for themselves. Australians are tending to live a lot longer and we must continue to expand the facilities available to this group. In living their ordinary lives they have contributed greatly to the development of Australia and we have now a responsibility, one that is well recognised by this Government, to repay them in their twilight years. That is a time when the nation can show its gratitude and discharge its obligation. I believe that the Government is doing so.

Housing is a matter of importance, a fact that I believe all governments, be they Liberal or Labor, do recognise. I do not like to make political points about it but I must say that the Liberal policy of emphasising private housing, and making maximum finance available at sensible interest rates, is better than the Government trying to build houses and then rent them to people. I believe that in housing there are good signs for the future; that interest rates will come down just as those in the United States have come down. Lending is on the increase again and, after the low that was reached a few months ago, confidence is returning to the housing market. As I and others have stated before, the provision for welfare housing is continually being increased.

On the day on which the Australian Labor Party, which largely is backed by the unions, has placed before the Senate a motion that it is a matter of public importance that we discuss 'The failure of the Goverment to devise a national policy in order to provide adequate housing at a manageable cost for all Australians', on the front page of the Canberra Times appears the heading ' Building unions seek $40 rise'. That refers to a rise of $40 a week. That will affect 100,000 workers, including carpenters, joiners, bricklayers, stone-masons , plasterers and will add tremendously to the cost of a house. Such increases will affect people trying to obtain a house quite as much as will high interest rates, but interest rates can come down, wage costs never do. Perhaps the matter of public importance should have been worded:
The failure of the building unions to recognise that their greed in seeking large pay rises will lead to some people in Australia not being able to afford to build their own home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to join in this debate today. My role is to support my colleagues in regard to this matter by looking at the current situation in the Northern Territory, where the Federal Government has had the responsibility for housing over the years. I will look at the special problems that exist in the Northern Territory and at what can be done to improve the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I move into that area I must respond to a couple of the comments which were made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). He said that there had been increases in housing grants. I propose to cite the figures given in Budget Paper No. 7. The honourable senator mentioned welfare housing so I will mention pensioner housing grants in the Northern Territory. The amounts allotted have been: In 1979-80, $1.5m; 1980-81, $1.6m; 1981-82, $0.5m; and 1982- 83 also $0.5m. That certainly does not represent an increase at all. The amounts have not even kept up with inflation.

If we move from the Northern Territory to look at the scene overall we see that Commonwealth net advances, in constant prices, for housing in the States and the Territories in 1982-83 are less than one third the amount provided in 1974-75. The actual figures are: In 1974-75, $975m; 1975-76, $935m; 1976-77, $835m; 1977- 78, $674m; 1978-79, $460m; 1979-80, $330m; 1980-81, $299m; 1981-82, $237m; and 1982-83, $290m. In other words, in constant terms, the amount to be advanced in 1982-83 is one third of the amount advanced in 1974-75. Yet Senator Townley had the audacity to come into this place and say that the Australian Labor Party had not done the right thing by housing.

Let us look at those figures a little further. The cumulative real reduction in public housing funds over that eight-year period has been a staggering $3,740m. The maintenance of public housing funds at the 1974-75 level would have meant the provision of an additional 75,000 dwellings. Yet the Government has the cheek to say that Labor was not giving attention to housing. The Minister also spoke about home ownership. I think he was very game to do so. At present it is more difficult to get a job than it has ever been in our history. Equally, it is more difficult to get a house than it has ever been in our history. Before World War I, according to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, it took 18 months' pay of the average worker to buy a house. This year it takes four years of the average wage to buy a house. The CSIRO report made this comment:
. . . the problem with the affordable home-which was once affordable by about 80 per cent of eligible Australians-is that most of us cannot now afford one!

In other words, the term has no meaning. Senator Chaney said that the Government wants to keep the levels of home ownership high; that he believes the present Government will do that. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) does not agree with him. The Treasurer has stated: 'We need to accept a declining level in home ownership'. Senator Chaney then made a few more gratuitous remarks about Labor, which I think I have covered. He said also that the flow of funds to housing would continue-a view not shared by most of the economists. Senator Townley made the same sort of comment. I think such comments fall into the same region of pious hope into which most of the Government's propositions fall.

The Minister referred to increases in assistance and mentioned the assistance given to pensioners. We must ask, when we use figures such as this, what is the base figure from which this wonderful increase has come? The Minister chose to talk about the generosity of the Government to pensioners. I am afraid his view is not shared by the Australian Council of Social Service or by any of the other major agencies. They indicate that under the present Government we have more aged pensioners and other pensioners living below the poverty line. Later Senator Chaney, by way of an interjection when Senator Jones was speaking, challenged the church's figures and said that they were rubbery. He smiled when the Opposition referred to the fact that they might be a little bit like the Budget figures. Let me assure the Minister that the figures given by the churches and the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry were valid at the time. The bases on which the figures were taken were valuable and could have been used by the Minister. It is the usual technique of the present Government to try to discourage any sort of criticism by attacking personalities .

I turn now to the situation which exists in the Northern Territory. I am drawing my facts from a report produced at the end of last year on Northern Territory housing needs. I have no doubt that the report will be challenged by the Minister in due course as containing some sort of rubbery figures. The figures have been produced by various departments in the Northern Territory and I am sure they will be valid and that we can make use of them. First, I turn to the situation of home ownership in the Northern Territory. The percentage of people living in their own homes in the six urban centres of the Northern Territory is 29.1 per cent. The national average is 72 per cent. That means that in excess of 70 per cent of the people in the the Northern Territory are living in rented homes, government homes or caravans. I should like to talk about caravans because they have already been mentioned in this debate. The number of people living in caravans in the Northern Territory is 12 per cent of the population. The national average is 0.5 per cent. The number living in caravans in the Northern Territory is 24 times the national average. I do not need to go into that socially undersirable situation. I refer to the fact that the situation that exists in the Northern Territory at the present time has resulted because of the Federal Government's lack of activity. In case the Government wants to talk about the situation that applied when the Labor Government was in office I remind it of the wonderful work done by that Government in 1975 following Cyclone Tracy. It instituted the greatest building program ever seen. It is not surprising that the people of the Northern Territory, after Cyclone Tracy, said: 'Thank God for a Labor government'. After a cyclone in Queensland this Government sent a telegram of condolence and nothing else.

I wish to move from home ownership in the Northern Territory to the renting of houses. This becomes pretty much an academic exercise because there are virtually no rental houses in the Northern Territory. The Real Estate Institute of Australia suggests that we need a total of 3 per cent to 4 per cent unoccupied houses to give some sort of balance so that a reasonable number of houses are available for rental. This does not exist in the Northern Territory, and we have unrealistic rents. I should like to look quickly at the results of a survey of rents carried out by the Real Estate Institute of Australia. The survey showed that the weekly rental for a three bedroom home in Sydney was $80; in Melbourne, $70; in Brisbane, $80; in Adelaide, $60; in Perth, $40; in Canberra, $85; and in Darwin, $150. Again, I point out that very few houses are available for rental in the Northern Territory. Senator Jones made the point, of course, that people who live in these houses have very little or no chance to save the money for a deposit on a home. According to figures produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics the cost of homes in the Northern Territory is 27 per cent above the national average. What is the reason for this? Why is it so expensive? First, freight costs are considerable because of the distance goods have to be transported. Secondly, sales tax is paid on freight. That is something which I have asked this Government to look at but it has refused point blank to do so. That means that people in the Northern Territory have to pay sales tax on freight. The freight cost is included on everything that is brought to the Northern Territory, and we have to pay sales tax on that freight. So much for a government that is trying to bring down the cost of housing! The Government is not fair dinkum, but we knew that of course because in the 1981 Budget it put a 2.5 per cent increase on the cost of building materials. It wanted to tax people on building materials. That would have pushed up the cost of housing. Fortunately, and rightly so, this proposition was knocked out in the Senate. What occurred in 1982? We saw a 7 per cent tax on hand tools and construction equipment. Again, that is an action of a government that is not dinkum about wanting to bring down the cost of housing. Also in the Northern Territory, of course, we have the problems of cyclone proofing. We must also consider that work can be carried out only in the dry season and that there are very few major businesses so there is not much competition.

Let us look at the Federal involvement in the housing situation in the Northern Territory. I ask honourable senators to remember that the housing position in the Northern Territory was inherited from the Commonwealth Government. The same situation applies to housing as education, about which the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) has often talked in this place . He has said that when he handed over responsibility for education to the Northern Territory Government in 1978 it was the best system in Australia. I do not have time to go into the comments that have been made in the Northern Territory since education was handed over in 1978 but certainly very few people have suggested that it is the best system in Australia.

I should like to mention also the situation of the Commonwealth public servants who were working in the Northern Territory in 1977-78 prior to independence who wanted to buy their own homes. The Federal Government put a freeze on the purchase of government homes. Public servants had lived in these homes for 10 years and, in many cases, had spent thousands of dollars on improvements. What did the Federal Government do? It said: 'You cannot buy them'. In other words the Government reneged on the sort of contracts it had made with people when they had agreed to go to the Northern Territory. The Government broke the employment conditions which led to disgruntled public servants. This built up a feeling of low morale for years in the Northern Territory.

This report on the Northern Territory deals with a number of areas. It claims that the Federal Government has relegated housing to a lower political, social and economic priority. This conscious decision of the Government has affected the Northern Territory. The Treasurer talks of the need to accept declining levels of home ownership. He thinks that home ownership is no longer the Australian dream, despite what Senator Chaney and Senator Townley have said. The Northern Territory people were told: 'It is one of those things you cannot have' . Funds under the housing agreements have declined in real terms. We have seen the dramatic figures which show that the funds are one-third of what they were in 1974-75. Despite what Senator Townley said there is very little prospect of relief from the current high interest rates on housing finance. In other words, a summary of the report is this: Home prices are rising, and housing finance is scarce and can be obtained only at a high cost.

My colleague Senator Tate has indicated what an Australian Labor Party would do on the national scene. I should like to indicate what needs to be done on the Northern Territory scene. First, we should make sure that sufficient serviced land is available at a reasonable price. The price ought to be kept down to cost ; in other words, the amount of money that it costs the Government to service the land ought to be the price at which it is handed over to the buyer. We want to keep the Housing Commission involved. We do not want to involve it only in welfare housing, as the Minister wants, but in the whole area of cheaper housing , because that is the key. The key to the whole issue is the encouragement of cheaper housing. At this stage I should like to commend the Northern Territory Government for the work it has done in trying to get cheaper housing for the people of the Northern Territory. It has run competitions. It has established a small village where people can go to see a range of cheaper housing which they can perhaps build on their own block of land. In the same way, the Northern Territory Government has encouraged the building of a variety of houses. We do not need all houses to be three bedroom houses. We need townhouses, flats, two bedroom homes and houses of different sizes so that there can be movement between them.

An Australian Labor Party government would provide the advice that people in the Northern Territory need. It would conduct research, as has been indicated by Senator Tate. It would use the results of such research to assist the people in the Northern Territory to buy cheaper homes; in this way they can work towards having their own homes. An Australian Labor Party government would review the home loans scheme so that it generally assisted people on lower incomes to buy their own homes. That is not the sort of situation we have seen where a person who wanted to buy a $97,000 house was given a loan because he was able to raise that sort of money. The Opposition's policy is aimed not only at welfare housing but also at housing for the ordinary, average person. The Liberals used to talk about the dream home, but it has done nothing.

An Australian Labor Party government would make sure that the scheme served as a complement to funds available from financial institutions. It would also encourage the savings banks to provide more finance for housing. In the Northern Territory, only 22 per cent of deposits are available for housing. The national average is 51 per cent; it is 22 per cent in the Northern Territory. An Australian Labor Party government would ensure that that amount was increased so that money would come from the right place, the banks. The Opposition has outlined what needs to be done. It has briefly commented on Government activity and inactivity. It has clearly shown the failure of the Government to devise or implement a national policy on housing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week in the speech I made on the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1982 I accused the Government of being insufficiently committed to the provision of public housing. I noted then that the Government had failed to consider the increasing demand for public housing, a demand which I pointed out was increasing because of the damage being done by other government action, specifically its commitment to the deregulation of interest rates. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), in response last week and again in his speech today, made the point that the Government has allocated a total of $903m to welfare housing for the 1982-83 financial year, an increase of about 45 per cent. For that, of course, he is to be commended. Yet I suggest that this does not alter the fact that the amount of reasonably priced, adequate housing available in Australia at the moment is patently insufficient. The increasing unemployment situation will exacerbate that problem; a problem which is succinctly outlined in House and Home, the document I referred to last week which was put out by the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace. It is a document which, of course, has been referred to repeatedly, and with some justification, during the debate today. That document notes, amongst other things, that whilst the average number of rooms per dwelling in Australia is five and a half, 2 per cent of dwellings, some 80,000, have only one or two rooms and 5 per cent of dwellings, 200,000, do not have a kitchen or do not have a bathroom, or do not have either. The document goes on to make the point:

SPEECH.PARA: For those who do share in the available housing, the distribution is unequal.

It cites, for example, the 40,000 people who live alone in housing with four or more bedrooms and compares that with the 160,000 people who live in groups of eight or more in housing which has only one, two or three bedrooms. That is a situation which I suggest we tend to associate more with China or countries equally populated, such as India.

The Women's Information Switchboard in Adelaide receives a very large number of calls about accommodation problems. Most of these, naturally enough, are from women and, in the main, are from women with children. If women are on the widows pension or the supporting parents benefit the only way they can survive is to move in with somebody else in the same situation and to become part of that group mentioned in House and Home. It is not easy to live with another family, even if one is related to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is harder.

—Yes, it very likely is harder in some cases. I presume the honourable senator is speaking from experience. In many cases these women want desperately, as do most Australians, to live on their own, independently, with their children while they recover from whatever trauma it is that has put them into that situation, generally a marriage breakdown. Often the arrangements they are able to make are of very short duration and lead to a very unstable life- style, which is particularly traumatic for their children, many of whom already have a damaged sense of security caused by the breakdown of their parents' relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: The Women's Information Switchboard was kind enough this afternoon to provide me with a number of examples of the sorts of problems which are referred to it and which come from families on the South Australian Housing Trust priority listing. I interpolate at this point that the South Australian Housing Trust does a magnificent job with the limited resources available to it. One case the Switchboard cited to me was that of a woman who arrived from Portland-I am sorry , from Poland-last month. Portland may be, as far as some South Australians are concerned, just as much a foreign country or an element of a foreign country, as Poland, but this lady actually came from Poland. Her husband had sponsored her and her three children aged 18, 15 and 5 years, to come to this country. As soon as they arrived he put them in a rented house, took all her money and deserted her for another woman.

The situation is, of course, exacerbated by the fact that no one in the family can speak English. They have no family here, no friends here and so far have the support of only a few members of the Polish community. Her rent is $55 a week and her landlord is now harassing her and saying that she should be paying $70 a week. To date, at least as far as the Women's Information Switchboard is concerned, the Department of Social Security has not decided what sort of pension, if any, she is eligible to receive. She has received only two payments of special benefits, one of $130 and one of $180. Of course, her 18-year-old daughter receives the unemployment benefit. It is people like this woman and her children who are forced to rely on those houses supplied by the South Australian Housing Trust. But if we are to believe an article which appeared in the Australian on 5 October this year, the State Housing Trust could face bankruptcy . The article stated in its opening paragraph:
The South Australian Housing Trust could face bankruptcy within five years if it is forced increasingly to rely on semi-government loans charging market interest rates.

It is a rather absurd situation to force an organisation such as a State housing trust or a housing commission into liquidation when it is struggling desperately to provide as much low-cost or low-rental housing to people as it can. An article which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser on 24 July-in the middle of winter, I point out-was entitled 'Homeless teenagers sleep in clothing bins'. It elaborated on that by saying, in relation to the Noarlunga area, an extremely southern and rather isolated area of suburban Adelaide:
Homeless teenagers are sleeping in St Vincent de Paul clothing bins, under bridges and on bus seats in Noarlunga, according to a local welfare worker.
She said Noarlunga's critical accommodation shortage meant hundreds of young people were homeless.
'One-fifth of the 100 seeking refuge I've seen this year were sleeping rough.' Mrs Pichler said.
In one case, seven youths were sharing a two-bedroom house.
'A 16-year old I saw had been arrested for illegally using a motor vehicle,' . . .
'But it was his third night out and, after sleeping under a bridge-
I stress again that this is in July--
he couldn't resist the comfort of an unlocked car.

As I pointed out last week, these young people are particularly vulnerable when it comes to trying to find access to housing. Amongst the others who are vulnerable-the point is made again in House and Home-are social security beneficiaries whose weekly income is frequently below the poverty line; young families, especially those with children, who are at present renting, particularly in the private market; and, of course, Aborigines. Although, as I pointed out last week, the problem is worst in city areas, it is also spreading to country areas as people move there in the hope of finding more available accommodation.

The Women's Information Switchboard in Adelaide is aware of a woman with two children-a boy aged 12 and a girl aged 10-living in a converted bus in the South Australian country area of Mt Barker. I understand the bus is primitive in many respects, having for instance only commode-type toilet facilities. All her attempts to find more suitable accommodation within her means-she is on a widows ' pension-have failed despite the fact that she has tried everything from emergency housing to direct approaches for private rental. Part of the problem comes from the fact that she is, quite understand- ably, concerned to maintain some stability for her children and therefore wants to remain in the Mt Barker area, where the little boy and girl are attending school. If she moves too far away from there and wants to maintain their educative stability she will be unable to afford their bus fees. The last the Women's Information Switchboard heard was that the owner of the bus had given her 11 days to vacate. These are not isolated examples. They concern merely a few of the growing number of people who are forced to turn to charitable organisations of one sort or another, to sleep out in the open, to share cramped accommodation with other people and in effect to live in totally inadequate forms of shelter-certainly for a country such as Australia, which prides itself on being civilised. While this sort of situation continues, I suggest that we can do nothing other than to argue that this Government has failed in the past seven years to devise a national policy to provide adequate housing at a manageable cost for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated, we are debating a matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to devise a national policy in order to provide adequate housing at a manageable cost for all Australians.

All speakers from both sides of the House have agreed that the lack of housing is a matter of public importance. The fact that there is not adequate housing- that too many people are not in housing of a suitable standard-is not a situation that anybody on either side of the chamber approves. We do have, and have had, an overall policy; this was enunciated by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) when he spoke in this debate. It is a policy which works in conjunction with all the States. But I must say that housing is basically a State responsibility. Although plenty of people try to level accusations at the Federal Government, for what it is doing or what it should be doing in a whole host of matters, housing is basically a State responsibility. We channel our finances through the States. Despite that, there are two Ministers in the Federal Government who have a responsibility for housing.

It is not that housing has a low priority or, as has been suggested, a lower priority than it should have. I reiterate that it is basically a State responsibility. We provide funds and channel those funds through the States for their implementation in various ways. We recognise that there are problems. As I said at the outset, none of us is happy that there are people without adequate housing; we would be most inhuman if we were. We recognise the problems and, through the co-operation of Federal and State governments, since the war the percentage of people either owning or buying their own home has increased from 54 per cent-I think that figure was in 1947-to 70 per cent now, which is not a bad record. The Minister outlined some of the percentages in other countries. When we consider that in the United Kingdom 50 per cent of people are buying or own their own homes, in Canada the figure is 62 per cent, in the United States of America it is 65 per cent and in West Germany it is 33 per cent, Australia has a pretty good percentage.

In fairness to our country, before we rubbish it too much-which seems to be a pastime of Australians-we should look at the peculiar position of Australia. Considering the large land mass of Australia vis-a-vis its small population and the situation of the population, I think Australians should be continually reminded that they have not done too badly as a nation less than 200 years old. It is one of the harshest and driest continents on this earth. We have a land mass about the size of the continental United States and a population which is about one-fourteenth its size. So we have a tremendous demand on our resources for communications and transport. When one considers what we have achieved in the way of housing, this country has done very well. That does not mean to say that we need to rest on our laurels. We have consistently allocated special funding for the disadvantaged in our community, namely, the pensioners and the Aborigines. I do not think anybody would have any quarrel with that.

The Australian Labor Party has a policy consisting mainly of pious platitudes. I guess a lot of political policies fall into that category, but it is the Australian Labor Party that is criticising us. It talks about continual assessment and monitoring of the situation, co-ordination of funding, encouraging participation of institutions, local governments and community groups, and about a Green Paper. All those pious platitudes are there. In fairness, it gets down to the nitty gritty of what it perceives should be done. I find that part of it a bit horrifying. It talks about an increase in public ownership and of introducing more bureaucratic controls, which ultimately lead to a distortion of the financial system. I remind honourable senators that that was the situation in which we found ourselves at the end of 1975. It is all right to say that so much money was put into housing-indeed, it was-but the country was left with a massive debt which accumulated over those three years and for which we are still paying.

Interest rates are a subject that always comes to people's minds when we are talking about housing-and quite rightly so. But I think it must be acknowledged that, in an uncontrolled atmosphere, interest rates reflect the value of the money on the day. Housing interests rates are controlled; there are no two ways about that. They are controlled mainly through the building societies and that is done by State governments. But they are controlled at a rate considerably lower than the market rate. One thing a lot of people find it hard to recognise is that, when there are low interest rates such as with the building societies, there is a small or a smaller amount of money available. This is the situation in which this country has found itself. Interest rates have been controlled for housing. They have been lower than market rates and, consequently, there has been less money available for housing, which is one of the problems. As I said, not many people realise that as a problem, but nonetheless it is.

I was discussing the problem of interest rates with a builder one day. He made the point that, even though interest rates are higher than they were two years ago, that is not the problem with new building. It is the lack of money. He indicated to me that his experience is that people building a new home cut their cloth to suit. In other words, they buy a home, the repayments on which they can meet out of their income. Many honourable senators in this place will be in the position of buying and paying off a home and having to meet the increased interest rates. It is a problem and it has created some hardship for many families. It was indicated by Senator Robertson, quite rightly, that pre-war one could buy a house more easily with so many weeks wages than is the case now. I submit that people's expectations in housing are considerably greater than they were pre-war. I dare say that, in those days, carpet, plush curtains, fittings, dishwashers, washing machines and all the rest-the list is almost endless-were unheard of.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't say that was wrong though, Senator, would you?

—I am not saying that it is wrong. I am indicating that these days people's expectations are considerably higher than they were in those days. When I bought my first home, a wood copper sufficed-and I have no quarrel with that either. I am just making the point that those expectations are greater and, to meet those expectations, the cost is considerably higher. But people can withdraw from what might be considered basic needs to minimise their financial commitments. As the builder friend of mine indicated, that is happening with new buildings; people build to suit their financial capabilities. Another thing that is continually happening is that we are seeing new methods of construction and new materials. Someone once said that if a person built a better mousetrap the world would beat a path to his door. A fair amount of onus has been put on the building industry to change its methods of construction and to look at better materials. That has been done. We hear of pre-built houses and modular construction, and the list goes on. I think that will ultimately be to the advantage of everybody concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems is the cost. Senator Townley alluded to the fact that there was an application for wage increases recently. I dare say that nobody would be in disagreement with the fact that the shenanigans of the Builders Labourers Federation over the last few years are conducive to increasing building costs in this country. That is a cost that this nation will ulti- mately bear. Wage increases without a commensurate increase in productivity, take their toll on people who are trying to buy houses. One could put in that bracket the shorter working week. Once again I say that a shorter working week without a commensurate increase in productivity is also imposing a cost which is having its effect on the costs of the building industry and thus the ability of people to buy houses.

Just about every speaker has mentioned the fact that the churches bought into the argument in September. I have no quarrel with that. Churches see their role of social responsibility as looking after the disadvantaged in the community. That they have done although, by the way the matter was reported in some newspapers and the way some churches might have handled it, I think it was not so much just a look at the housing situation. Some of the churchmen see themselves as better politicians than theologians. The statement came out in rather more political terms than a theological dissertation on the necessity for social responsibility for the people of this country. But I guess we are getting used to that coming from some sections of the churches in this day and age. But they quite rightly drew the attention of the community to the problems. I think some of the proposals put by the churches were basically demands for more money. I guess that if we had adequate funding we could solve many problems.

The statements also mentioned tenancy laws. It is one thing to say that the tenant needs to be protected. The landlord also needs to be protected. I am a little conversant with the current situation in the United Kingdom where there are very strict tenancy laws which are having an adverse effect. Many houses are empty due merely to the fact that the landlords will not put people into them because the tenancy laws are so strict. The landlords really have no protection against errant tenants. So the laws have been counter-productive in that country . The landlords are very choosey about who they put into their houses. As a result many houses are staying empty for a long time.

The Government is mindful of the problems in the housing industry. In March we brought in a housing package which provided a tax rebate for first home buyers; more money for housing -$400m; new and improved deposit assistance through the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme; and mortgage and rent relief. In the Budget we took that package a little further. There has been an increase of $71m in the amount allocated to welfare housing this year, which takes the allocation to $ 333m for 1982-83. That is an increase of 27 per cent. Additional funds for supplementary assistance and rent relief for pensioners have been made available . There is quite a good list of measures which show that the Government has tried to bite the bullet and do something for the housing industry. It is doing so more particularly for those who are seeking housing.

Many honourable senators have alluded to the recent signs that interest rates are coming down. That can only be an ultimate benefit. If one looks to those who are interested in housing-the Real Estate Institute-one can see that they have welcomed the Government's initiatives. Queensland is a little more fortunate in that the Queensland Minister for Works and Housing has brought in a supplementary scheme which will be of benefit to the people in that State. I would agree that housing is a matter of public importance but I would not agree with the claim that this Government has in any way failed to meet its responsibilities. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
