DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in view of (a) the deterioration in employment expectations revealed by the Treasurer's statement of 14 October 1982, (b) the continuing drought, and (c ) delays in passing and changes to the Government's proposed tax legislation, the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations inquire into the effect of these factors on the Budget revenue estimates, and report to the Senate on 11 November 1982 and that, specifically, the Committee seek evidence from the Treasury on the likely revenue changes for 1982-83 in regard to:
(1) The effect on PAYE receipts of a lower level of employment.
(2) The effect of the continuing drought and lower farm incomes on provisional tax collections from farmers (due on 31 March 1983) caused by farmers exercising the option to vary provisional tax.
(3) The effect on company tax collections of the apparent fall in business profits in the second half of fiscal year 1981-82.
(4) The effect on sales and excise tax collections caused by the negative Gross Domestic Product growth implicit in lower employment levels and the drought.
(5) The current estimates of the revenue cost of the health insurance rebate.
(6) The effect on tax recoupment receipts of the delay in enacting the recoupment legislation which the Treasurer predicted in July would pass both Houses of Parliament on or before 26 August 1982.
(7) The effect of reducing the interest payment from 30 to 20 per cent on overdue recoupment assessments.
(8) The effect on PAYE receipts of a reduction from 12 to 10 per cent of increases in average earnings.
(9) Any other revenue changes expected in view of more recent information.

In a few moments I shall seek leave of the Senate to amend that motion to change the date 11 November to 28 October. It is now quite clear that there will be a major blowout in the Government's published deficit, owing to both an expenditure overrun and a revenue shortfall. On the Government's own admission, the expenditure will overrun by at least $656m from two items. The first is the drought relief appropriation, which came in after the Budget, estimated at this stage at $356m. Information recently gained by the Opposition suggests that the actual figure could be closer to $600m. The second is the $300m addition to unemployment benefit payments to which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) admitted last Thursday. The latter, the increase in unemployment benefit payments, is a function of the deepening economic recession, of the economic collapse. That collapse will also affect revenue from various sources, we believe by at least as much as the expenditure overrun. I will supply more details of that later.

Revenue examination is the subject of this motion. The motion seeks an examination of the accuracy of the revenue estimates previously supplied. It has nothing to do with the Appropriation or any other Budget Bills, including the Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill. That distinction may not be clear to all, especially when the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in conformity with his usual practice, seeks to misrepresent the facts. It is apparently and regrettably not clear to the Australian Democrats either. In a statement issued this afternoon, the Australian Democrats stated:

. . . they are not prepared to support the Labor Party in its proposals to recall Estimates committees and to embark on the fishing expedition proposed by Senator Walsh which would take several months to complete.
The statement continues:
Without Supply drought sufferers, the unemployed and pensioners would immediately suffer.

This motion, I stress again, will not hold up Appropriation or other Bills, nor will the motions that Senator Button proposes to move later. It will, therefore, have no effect on payments to drought sufferers, the unemployed, pensioners or indeed payments to any other group. It is concerned entirely with revenue estimates, not expenditure. I hope that the newspapers which have been misled by that confusion will devote the same attention to correcting their errors that they have devoted to publishing the misunderstanding in the first place.

There are two errors in the statement by the Australian Democrats. On the first , it will not take several months to complete the investigation which I am proposing in this motion or the investigations which Senator Button will propose later. Indeed, this investigation which I am proposing could be completed in a one-day hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations if questions were submitted to the Treasury in writing tomorrow, which the Opposition proposes to do if the motion is carried. A sitting of the Finance and Government Operations Committee could then be arranged for next Monday, if so desired. The notice of motion itself is probably sufficient to give the Treasury the sort of warning that is required to prepare by next Monday answers to the specific questions detailed in the notice of motion. However, for those who continue to have trouble in distinguishing between an investigation of revenue estimates and the appropriation of moneys for expenditure, the Opposition is prepared to make a concession. I seek leave to amend the date included in my motion, 11 November, to 28 October.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also note in passing that there is an incorrect date on the official Notice Paper with reference to the year in which the relevant provisional tax assessments will fall due. The official Notice Paper said 1982. It should have been 1983, as indeed it was in the notice of motion submitted. The revenue estimates cannot, as has been suggested, be dealt with by the Committee of the Whole in examining the Appropriation Bills. Standing Order 263 states:

SPEECH.PARA: A Committee-
That is, the Committee of the Whole-
shall consider such matters only as shall have been referred to it by the Senate .

That is, in the instance of the Appropriation Bills, the Committee shall consider only the Appropriation Bills. Speakers are limited to appropriation items and can be directed by the Chair to confine their remarks to them. The Committee of the Whole, in dealing with the Appropriation Bills, offers no opportunity to examine the accuracy of revenue estimates. Moreover, in the Committee of the Whole, on any question at all, public servants cannot be directly questioned by senators as they can in Senate committee hearings, either Estimates or other standing committees.

The Finance and Government Operations Committee is the appropriate committee to examine the revenue estimates. The Chairman of that Committee, regrettably, is absent from Australia. But that is not an insurmountable problem. Standing Order 297A provides that a meeting of the Committee may be called by the secretary upon request by not less than three members of the Committee. I know that there are at least three members of that Committee who would call for such a meeting if this motion were passed. The combined result of both the expenditure overrun and the revenue shortfall is that the deficit, we believe, will blow out by something between $1.5 billion and $2 billion. As Senator Sir John Carrick said on 1 October 1975:
This is a simple situation. We need to know whether the deficit is to remain at $2,798m or whether it is on its way to doubling.

We believe the deficit is on its way to doubling and we seek confirmation of that belief in the proper way and in accordance with the procedures already laid down for the business of the Senate. That deficit, which with the blowout will total between $3.2 billion and $3.7 billion, can be financed in three ways. Printing money-or borrowing from the Reserve Bank, which is sometimes rather loosely referred to as printing money-and borrowing overseas are two of the ways . Both of these ways have the effect of increasing the money supply, unplanned increases which the Government assures us would be responsible. The third method of funding that deficit would be to borrow the required funds from the Australian public. Obviously that would require an increase of between $1 1/2 billion and $2 billion in the planned public sector borrowing requirement.

An increase in the public sector borrowing requirement has some implications for interest rates. It has implications particularly for home buyers, some of whom may have been seduced by the belief that interest rates are about to fall. A blowout in the public sector borrowing requirement of that magnitude, other things being equal, will not only put paid to those hopes but also would be very likely to induce further increases in interest rates paid by home buyers. I quote the Treasurer on this matter. He has said:
Either the public sector borrowing requirement has to be reduced, or there will be higher interest rates or higher inflation-or both.

It follows axiomatically, according to the Treasurer, that if the public sector borrowing requirement is increased, particularly if it is increased by that magnitude, there must be upward pressure on interest rates. According to the Government in general, up until very recently the public sector borrowing requirement was the cause of the record interest rates currently prevailing. The public is entitled to know the degree to which the deficit will blow out, and this motion seeks to clarify the degree to which shortfalls in revenue estimates will contribute to that blowout. The public is entitled to know and the Senate is obliged to find out. I am disappointed that only the Australian Labor Party, at least as of an hour ago, and with the possible exception of Senator Harradine , whose views I do not know, accepts that obligation.

There was-I stress the past tense-a fourth possibility for coping with the deficit blowout. There could have been a huge tax slug in a February mini-Budget , an exercise similar to that of 1977. That was the prime ministerial plan based on a prime ministerial delusion that the Government could pull and win a premature election before the economy collapsed, or at least before the public became aware of the collapse. The public is entitled to know the degree to which revenue estimate errors are excusable and the degree to which they may be attributed to rubbery estimates, rubbery being a euphemism for false estimates designed to produce what the Prime Minister would regard as a more respectable deficit-a Prime Minister, remember, who is manically obsessed with a premature election. In 1975, Senator Baume said:

It seems, as I have said, that already receipts in the Budget have been maximised, that expenditure has been minimised and that the Government has sought artificially to show the smallest possible deficit as a going in position for the beginning of the financial year. Our job is to examine just how far from reality this is likely to be.

I invite Senator Baume to stand by the beliefs he expressed then and vote for this motion. Our job, as he said then, is to examine just how far from reality this is likely to be. That is precisely what the motion seeks to do-to examine, in the light of more recent knowledge and perhaps a more objective assessment of knowledge previously available, just how far from reality it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Democrats support that?

—I hope they do, but regrettably this afternoon they misunderstood what the motion was about and issued a Press statement saying that they would not vote for it. I invite Senator Baume to stand by the view he expressed in 1975 and vote for this motion which seeks to determine just how far from reality are the estimates of revenue previously given by the Government. Our job-a job, regrettably, that it appears only the Labor Party will undertake-is to determine just that. I trust and sincerely hope that the views of other members of the Senate will change.

SPEECH.PARA: How inaccurate are the estimates which have previously been supplied and by how much must they be adjusted? A crucial factor in answering that question is the admission by the Treasurer last Thursday that the number of unemployment benefit recipients would average through this financial year 460,000 instead of the 395, 000 previously estimated. The Government has acknowledged that, on average, 65, 000 more people will be unemployed this financial year than it earlier thought. The corollary of that increase in unemployment is that employment will fall by around one per cent and when employment falls pay-as-you-earn tax collections inevitably fall also, although probably by a slightly lesser proportion. A one per cent decrease in the number of people employed, which is the corollary of the increase in unemployment which the Treasurer gave last week, entails a revenue loss in the order of $200m.

The drought is significantly worse than when the Budget Estimates were prepared . The Bureau of Agricultural Economics released yesterday an estimate that the net farm produce will be down by more than $1,100m over the BAE's earlier estimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose you blame that on the Government too, do you?

—I am not blaming it on the Government, I just want to know the revenue implications of it. I invite the honourable senator to join me and the Labor Party in voting for this motion so we can determine with the best possible information, which only the Government and the bureaucracy has, just what the revenue implications of the downturn in farm income are likely to be. If net farm product is down by more than $1,100m, taxable income will come down by almost as much. On 31 March provisional tax payments based on income earned by farmers in 1981-82 are due to be paid. It follows, therefore, that the income upon which those provisional tax assessments was based-that is, the income for the previous financial year-will be somewhat more than $1 billion in excess of the actual income. That will be apparent by 31 March 1983. Because the effects of the drought have not been uniform, the aggregate effect on the taxable incomes of all the individual farmers might be more significant than the whole industry effect. The point is that on or before the end of March the farmers may vary their provisional tax assessment. They are not obliged to vary them upwards but they may vary them downwards. Since those assessments have been based on a level of farm income more than $1 billion in excess of what is now the likely level of farm income, most of those provisional tax assessments will be varied downwards. The likely revenue cost of that will be in the order of $200m.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to company tax. A survey published in the Melbourne Age newspaper last week suggested that company tax collections could be nearly $600m lower than anticipated. That figure is almost certainly too high because it did not take account of time lags in the payment of provisional tax and large intra-year variations in company profits. Only the Australian Taxation Office could give accurate figures enabling those largely unknown variables to be quantified. But it is probable that, because of the very sharp fall in company profitability in the second half of the last fiscal year, company tax collections received this fiscal year will decline by around $300m.

The negative gross domestic product growth of between one per cent and 2 per cent which now clearly follows from the fall in employment levels and the drought will almost certainly lead to lower consumer spending and, therefore, lower collections of sales and excise taxes. A conservative estimate of the revenue effect of that is of the order of $50m. We have already had three different Government estimates for the health insurance rebate-an original estimate of $600m, followed some time later by an estimate of $470m and a Budget estimate of $506m. We believe that the original figure of $600m is the closest of the three. If that is so, the revenue cost this year of the health insurance rebate is underestimated by $100m.

Recovery of tax by the recoupment legislation is estimated in the Budget at $ 225m. I am not sure the precise basis on which that estimate was arrived at, but it certainly assumed that the legislation would have been enacted two months ago and that assessments would already have been issued. I quote from the early editions-it was not in the later edition in case someone goes to the trouble of checking in the Parliamentary Library-of the Sydney Sun of 26 July. An article in that paper stated:
Thousands of people in NSW who used the schemes and are now liable for tax could receive assessments as early as September.
This, of course, is in regard to the recoupment legislation. The report continues:
Mr Howard said he expected that special legislation aimed at acting retrospectively would be passed within a fortnight of Parliament resuming on August 17.

The Treasurer said he expected the legislation to be passed within two weeks of 17 August. Presumably, that being the Treasurer's expectation, that estimate of $225m recovered pursuant to the legislation incorporated the belief that the legislation would be passed by 26 August, which was in the second sitting week. Well, of course, as we all know, the legislation has not been enacted yet and the doubts persist as to whether it will be enacted in anything like its original form. It has not been enacted but it has been watered down. The original proposal of a 30 per cent penalty interest charge for late payment of assessments issued pursuant to the recoupment legislation has been watered down to 20 per cent. It remains to be seen in how many other respects the legislation might be watered down before the Government can get it past its own party room. But of this we can be certain: More than two months of the time which the Government originally believed was available to it to collect that revenue is no longer available. The revenue consequences of that could be as high as $100m.

This is not an exhaustive list, but it is as far as I have gone in determining reductions in the original estimates of revenue: Pay-as-you-earn tax, $200m; provisional taxation from farmers alone, $200m; company tax, $300m; sales and excise taxes, $50m; health rebate, $100m; and recoupment legislation, $100m. This makes a total of $950m. It is true that it is likely that there will be some increases in the estimates of tax collections. The only notable one, I believe, is the crude oil levy. There are, however, other possible shortfalls not included in that list, the most spectacular of which would be the $450m additional revenue the Government estimated it would get from increasing from 10 per cent to 20 per cent the penalties for late payments on ordinary assessments. That estimate may not be realised.

I make no claim to the figures I have presented being precise because we do not have all the relevant data. But a shortfall in aggregate of a magnitude of $1, 000m is clearly indicated by the evidence. If the Government wishes to deny that , let it do so in a credible way by stating the official revised estimates from an impartial bureaucracy before the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and allow honourable senators to do their duty and question and clarify those revised estimates. That can be done only if this motion is carried. I hope that those honourable senators who were previously either confused or nervous will now change their view and vote accordingly.

In conclusion, lest this aspect be misunderstood yet again, this motion deals solely with the accuracy of previous revenue estimates. It is absolutely divorced from any expenditure items, from any expenditure legislation. It has absolutely nothing to do with the Appropriation Bills, other Budget Bills or any appropriation introduced into the Parliament subsequent to the Budget. It will not affect payments to those affected by drought, the unemployed, pensioners or anyone else. What this motion will do, if it is carried, is permit the Senate to discharge the responsibility which has been given to it to do its duty by the people of Australia, to determine with a might higher level of accuracy the likely shortfall in revenue in this financal year and, therefore, the consequential increase in the Budget deficit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose this motion. It will do so primarily because the motion is demonstrably totally unrealistic. I will show that what is being sought is totally unrealistic. What otherwise is being sought could have been obtained at the extended hearings of the Estimates committees and could be obtained during debate on the Appropriation Bills which are to come before us and in any question and answer situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Fundamentally Senator Walsh's argument is that there will be a blow-out in expenditure; that there will be something terrible about this blow-out; that there will be a deficit of, on the basis of his calculations-I do not accept the figure-of the order of $3,300m, and that that would be very bad. He indulged in a lot of discussion and said that we would have difficulties with interest rates , borrowing, et cetera. Taking Senator Walsh's own figures, I have to say that his own leader, Mr Hayden, on 24 August said:
A domestic deficit of $1 billion to $1.5 billion-equivalent to much less than one per cent of gross domestic product-would have major multiplier effects throughout the economy.

Mr Hayden commended it. Such a domestic deficit represents an overall deficit of about $3.3 billion, which is precisely the one that Senator Walsh is now berating today. One knows that Mr Hawke did better than that. He thought that there should be a larger deficit. Without at all accepting the magnitude of the matter let me say in the first place that the whole basis on which he places his argument is nonsense. I want to demonstrate this because it is of very great importance. Let us bear in mind that Mr Hawke said that the Australian Labor Party, in government, would try to adopt a more expansionary program. He was talking about Budget deficits of $3 billion to $4 billion.

The matters that are being asked for in the motion include an estimate of how much drought relief will cost. The argument put forward is that somehow or other at the time of the Budget we should have known whether it was going to rain after 17 August and for how long it would have rained. The Opposition has made a great concession-after all, the original date of 11 November would have given us some more days-by insisting that by 28 October we will be able to predict whether it will rain in November, December, January or February, in other words when the drought will break. By some magic means, what could not have been known in July when the Budget was put together and what can never be known is supposed to be predictable now. How could these things be known? The Labor Party is berating us because, as it did not rain in August, September and October, we now seek to help the farming community. There is nothing that the Labor Party dislikes more than helping the farming community. The Government will be berated for doing that. The Government will be berated because in July and August it did not know that it was not going to rain in September, October or November. What is more, the Government will be asked to say on 28 October whether it will rain in November and December. That is demonstrably wrong. Underlying all this is the belief that what we have done is clumsy but what Labor would do would be better.

The second thrust of the motion is that payments for the unemployment benefit have been wrongly estimated and that that is some kind of a plot. I do not think that in 1974-75 the special Estimates committees were set up to look at the Crean Budget. We estimate an increase of 19 per cent in unemployment benefit recipients. In 1974-75, the number of unemployment recipients was 80 per cent higher than estimated at Budget time. The actual cost in revenue went up 68.9 per cent. We estimate that our increase will be 19.5 per cent. Let me demonstrate the Whitlam Government Budgets. Did the Whitlam Government say:'My goodness, the Budget is rubbery; the Budget is phoney'. Not one bit! Let us look at that aspect. In 1974-75, the number of unemployment recipients was 80 per cent higher than estimated at Budget time. That represented an increase of 68.9 per cent. In 1975-76-the Whitlam Government's next Budget-the number of recipients was 60 per cent higher than estimated at Budget time. Did that Government then say: 'Both our Budgets are in ruins'?

Let us consider this in terms of track records of Budgets into which the Opposition now says there ought to be special investigations. In 1972-73, expenditure on unemployment and sickness benefits was 34 per cent over the estimate. The following year, which was a Labor year, the figure was 39 per cent . The following year, which again was a Labor year, the figure was 68.9 per cent . The overlap for the next Labor year, 1975-76, was 40.5 per cent. Then the figure went to 28.2 per cent, 19.7 per cent, 11.3 per cent, minus 7.3 per cent, 3.9 per cent, 12.3 per cent and 19.2 per cent.

What is the pattern? The pattern is that in the Whitlam times clearly there were horrendous errors in judgment of estimate. Was there an investigation by that Government? Did it feel horror when placed in that situation? Just as in a drought situation where no one can safely say what will happen, it is not possible on 28 October to be able to say with any precision over the year whether disemployment will continue or whether there will be some re-employment. Factors can change. Let those who have this forethought in mind say so. Let us examine the position. The nonsense regarding the drought situation is demonstrable. The nonsense of the Opposition's claim that the Government is unskilled and it is skilful in relation to the unemployment benefit is cast out of the window. When one does the sums, one will see that they add up to a Budget deficit that Mr Hayden is advocating and Mr Hawke is advocating an even bigger one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not by accident, deliberately.

—Senator Tate says 'by accident'. Let us consider what happened, by accident, to the Hayden Budgets. They doubled and trebled their deficits on each of the occasions when they had the opportunity to do so.
—That is a lie! That is a lie!
—Order! I ask Senator Walsh to withdraw that remark.
—I ask Senator Carrick to withdraw what he said, that the estimated Budget deficits trebled under Mr Hayden.
—Senator Walsh, I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw and invite him to do the same.
—Senator Walsh, please withdraw, unconditionally.
—I withdraw.

—Let me take the steps one by one. Senator Walsh claimed that there would be a big fall-off in company taxation. Honourable senators heard that. One would have thought that he would have gone to the figures and would have been able to show us a fall-off. That is demonstrable. If he is going to ask the Government to take certain action, one would have thought that he knew that a fall-off occurred. Otherwise, why hold up the Senate and why get a Senate committee to inquire into the matter? We are told that nothing in company tax collections so far this year suggests the Budget estimate is too high. In the three months ending September, collections of company tax were $ 992m, that is, just $14m less than a quarter of the full year estimate. One can see the grave fall-off! Estimates of company tax collections are more practical in changing economic circumstances because the previous year is the relevant base year for the estimate.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures do not support Senator Walsh at all. Yet he says that this Senate should be hung up in an inquiry on these factors: A drought that no one could predict and unemployment figures on which his own party was immensely more inaccurate in a similar situation. Senator Walsh drummed up a deficit, and tried to pin it on us, which his own party leader and his front bench say is not big enough. What is he aiming at in this regard? Senator Walsh says that we should inquire into pay-as-you-earn receipts. How can we, by 28 October, know with any certainty what the trends will be? My advice from the Department of the Treasury is that it is too early to judge, that at this stage no major change is expected . The information can always be received by asking questions. We can get the view of the Treasury by simply posing the question.

If it is thought that receipts from pay-as-you-earn taxpayers will be lower, because average weekly earnings will be lower, the offset must also be considered. What about the contra? If that were so, the costs of running the Government would be lower. We heard nothing about that from the Opposition. For example, the table cited is a very selective little one. Why did not the honourable senator note the very interesting fact that the significant fall in interest rates will have an effect upon the amount of debt repayment, of interest servicing and so on? Why were these aspects not mentioned? Who can say that sales and excise tax collections will be lower because of drought and lower employment? In fact, the Treasury advises that typically rural consumers maintain their level of consumption by drawing on savings rather than forgoing consumption. That has been the pattern over the years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to people in rural areas and towns who are depending on that assistance.

—We will tell the rural people that the Government has been criticised with regard to drought support. We will be happy to tell the people of Tasmania, and everywhere else, of the Labor Party's attitudes in this regard and why it is trying to achieve delay. Why is it pressing the drought issue? It cannot be to ascertain the true cost, because nobody except the creator above knows that, it can only be because the Labor Party is opposed to the expenditure. That is the simple situation. It is now also being said that we will not obtain as much in revenue recoupment because we will start to collect a little later. But, as everyone knows, the Australian Taxation Office is at this moment preparing the assessments. If the legislation is passed, as it will be, the assessments will contain a time clause that will ensure collection will take place within the financial year. If not, penalties will be exacted.

SPEECH.PARA: We have an extraordinary situation in which it is said that an attempt is being made to obtain revenue estimates. Senator Walsh has stated clearly that the Opposition seeks estimates of the cost of drought relief. Demonstrably, such a proposition is absolute nonsense. The track record of all governments over the years, in terms of estimating the cost of unemployment benefit, has been demonstrably, specially in the case of Labor governments, worse than has been that of the Government on this occasion. So there has been no aberration in that regard. The actual size of the deficit that the Opposition is postulating and that it is attempting to pin on the Government-it is one that we do not accept- is, in fact, too low for the Labor Party itself. So what is the Opposition trying to do?

The honourable senator admitted that some extra revenue might be derived from oil levies, but honourable senators will notice that his figures did not take account of any of the pluses. The extra revenue from that source could be of the order of a couple of hundred million dollars. Quite clearly, if one takes the motion step by step it is demonstrably an absurd one to place before any committee. No committee can get a factual answer on these things because nobody can predict with any accuracy the future in regard to drought and such exigencies. Equally, a simple question in this place would suffice to obtain answers regarding those aspects that are predictable.

This motion is typical of the approach of the Labor Party, typical of its delaying tactics in this place. It spends its time in such pursuits. The amount of time that is being devoted to Government Business in the Senate is less than half of what it was when the Government had a majority. It is considerably less than half of what it was when the Labor Party was in office. We who were then in Opposition gave that Government the facilities to allow its business to proceed. But day by day-I can place the figures on record-the Labor Party is deliberately introducing such motions into the Senate simply to spin out time. This motion is typical of such devices; it cannot of itself achieve anything. The Labor Party has had the benefit of the many sitting hours of the Estimates committees. Fairly soon-later next week-it will have the opportunity to discuss the Appropriation Bills in detail. Also, it has the opportunity of asking questions at Question Time or on notice. The Government would be happy indeed to seek to obtain the information required.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are required to.

—Yes, the Government is required to do so. I made the comment simply to indicate a particular willingness to facilitate the acquisition of the information sought. We are required to impose a time limit upon it. Such estimates as it is possible to make are available to the Opposition without this kind of delay. I come back to the basis of the argument put by Senator Walsh: He needs to know the revenue implications because the Parliament needs to know the size of the deficit; it needs to know that because of the economic consequences in terms of borrowing, the effect on interest rates and other matters. He implies that if the deficit were of such a magnitude that would be bad. I repeat: The figures he used are modest compared with those advocated by Mr Hayden and very modest compared with those advocated by Mr Hawke . Against that background, the motion is demonstrably nonsense and should be rejected. Accordingly, the Government will reject it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are sympathetic to the reasons advanced by Senator Walsh and Senator Button for moving certain motions. We are sympathetic to the view that more information needs to be supplied to the Senate concerning this Budget, the underestimates and the other inaccuracies that have already been found in it. However, because of a pledge we took, the Democrats hold one thing as paramount- that we will not block or delay Supply to this or any other government. We believe that the effect of these Labor Party initiatives would be to delay Supply, not necessarily because of wishes or actions of the Labor Party but possibly because of the actions of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I, for one, will not hand Mr Fraser on a platter a reason to go to Yarralumla and ask for a double dissolution because ostensibly he has not the money to govern. As far as we are concerned, the paramount thing about these Appropriation Bills is that they should be expedited and passed without delay. Notwithstanding the intentions of the Labor Party in this matter which, being charitable, we assume to be good, the Democrats believe that the net result of these motions, if passed, would be to delay the passage of the Supply Bills.

If the Supply Bills are delayed, who will suffer? The drought affected, the pensioners and the unemployed will suffer. The Government will be able to say: ' We have not enough money because those nasty people in the Labor Party and those nasty Democrats have held up Supply'. That is a 3-card trick for which my colleagues and I will not fall.

I must say, without too much heat, that at the moment a game is being played in the national capital. It is a pretty disgusting game, given the state of crisis in which the country finds itself, one in which people are suffering in the ways that I have mentioned. But the game being played is prompted by the fact that the Prime Minister of this country, Mr Fraser, is obsessive about having an early election. He desperately wants one. Tony Eggleton does not, nor does Mr Anthony. Not one member of his Cabinet wants an early election, but Mr Fraser is obsessive. He has the trigger to go to Yarralumla tonight to get a double dissolution. The Senate has obliged him without fear or favour. Both the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have said that the Sales Tax Bills would not pass, knowing full well that that gave the Prime Minister grounds for a double dissolution. He has the mechanical means by which to seek a double dissolution. The media is totally behind him. An example of that is the disgraceful statement which appeared in last night's Melbourne Herald. It stated : 'Senate could not be trusted'. The person who wrote that outdid anybody on Malcolm Fraser's public relations staff. What should have been said was: The Senate cannot be trusted to be a rubber stamp. That would have been an accurate statement. I am pleased to say that nowadays the Senate is not a rubber stamp.

The game at the moment is that Mr Fraser does not have a reason that he can sell to the public to ask for a double dissolution even though he has the mechanical means to acquire one. What better excuse could he have than the Senate delaying Supply? That would give him the best reason of all for a double dissolution. He could blame the Senate for the plight of those suffering from the drought and make the other claims that I have mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is on the assumption that it would delay Supply.

—Yes. I thank Senator Button for that interjection. In the scenario that Senator Button paints it should not delay Supply and I concede that. I also concede-I do not impugn the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick-that if Senator Button were in his place he would use exactly the same tactics. If motions such as these were introduced and if Senator Button were requested by his leader to find an excuse for his leader to go to Yarralumla he would automatically say that the Senate would not contemplate the Supply Bills until the work proposed in the motions had been completed and until the committee had reported to the Senate. Even with the amended date of 28 October that Senator Walsh mentioned, in my reckoning that would still mean a two week delay before Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83 could be debated.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not an unduly suspicious person but I have a suspicion that the Government is running out of money faster than the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, hinted two or three days ago. I ask simply: Why is the Appropriation Bill (No. 1 ) 1982-83 to come into this chamber next Wednesday? Last week we were informed that it would come into this chamber on 9 November. Is there any great hurry? If there is a great hurry, what is the reason for it? Yesterday, at a meeting of the Whips, it was indicated that four Bills had to be passed before 31 October. Today, a fifth Bill was added to that list-a loan Bill. I regard that as highly significant. A government brings in a non-urgent loan Bill only if it is short of money. The Senate must forgive me if I am over-suspicious but I do not propose, nor does my party propose, to give to the Prime Minister this sort of shoddy excuse to call an early election.

If the Australian Democrats wanted to be self-centred and selfish there is nothing in political terms we would welcome more at this moment than an early election. We are prepared for it; we are ready for it. Every public opinion poll taken indicates that we would have at least one senator returned from each of the six States of the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not Western Australia.

—We would have a senator returned from Western Australia unless the Liberal Government engaged in the lies and deceit it engaged in last time. We would, currently running at a 13 per cent primary vote, return two senators, as we would in South Australia and Victoria. I imagine that we would have at least eight senators returned in place of our current five senators. From a selfish point of view, the Australian Democrats do not walk away from the prospect of a double dissolution. We have not walked away from such a prospect because we gave Mr Fraser the mechanical grounds to have a double dissolution many months ago when we voted against the imposition of the sales tax on the necessities of life. What effect would a double dissolution have on the country? A double dissolution now would mean another three to four months of instability. There would be normal instability leading up to an election campaign. Then there would be the Christmas period and the silly season of January. It would be February before any newly elected government-Labor or Liberal-could get down to the catastrophic problems facing this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 22 years I have been in this place I have never witnessed more irresponsible behaviour from a leader of this country than is presently being exemplified by the Prime Minister not saying 'there will be no early election' or 'there will be an early election'. We should be told one way or another. The Prime Minister cannot say that the Australian Democrats will go back on our promise never, under any circumstances, to block or delay Supply. If anybody should claim in the future that our statement about Supply is equivocal or that we have ever implied that we might delay or block Supply, that person would be telling a blatant and wilful lie.

We believe that the purposes for which the Labor Party has moved this motion are proper. We believe that it would, because of the engineering of politicians, provide an excuse for Mr Fraser to plunge the country into an election campaign. We think that is not in the interests of the country. I remind Senator Walsh and Senator Button that the Appropriation Bills are dealt with by Senate Estimates committees. During the hearings of those committees I have counted as many as 30 , 40 or 50 public servants in the Senate chamber and outside the Senate chamber ready to answer, admittedly through a Minister, questions posed by senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is the rub.

—Senator Button, my friend, said: 'There is the rub'. Senator Button probably does not remember because he did not have the fortitude to stay for the 15 hours last year when Senator McLaren cross-examined Ministers and public servants on the Estimates, but I can tell him that we were here for at least two hours while Senator McLaren, with his tenacity, probed and maintained questioning about the rate of interest Mr Anthony was paying on his government house. Finally, with the persistence of the Australian Democrats-we said we would not proceed until we got an answer-the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, was forced to go to the public servants and say: 'What is the figure? Give him the damn figure'. Senator McLaren was given the figure and justice prevailed.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Walsh wants the information which is outlined in his motion-I commend him for his motion-why does he not seek that information in writing today from the various Ministers? When the Senate goes into the Committee of the Whole why does not Senator Walsh say: 'Three weeks ago you got these letters in writing. What are the answers'? I give the Labor Party an undertaking that if those answers are not satisfactorily forthcoming then it will have the support of the Democrats to obtain those answers. That is a course of action which I believe comes within Standing Orders. It is proper. Under no circumstances would such a course of action give Mr Fraser a shonky excuse to go to Yarralumla to seek a double dissolution on false grounds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to vote against this motion because I consider it is a waste of the Senate's time. One has to consider whether the interests of people in the community, such as the unemployed and the farmers, will be advanced by this measure. In my view they will not. Appropriate avenues are available for this Senate, within its Standing Orders and within its usual procedures, for obtaining the information desired by this motion, one of which has been adverted to by Senator Chipp. He mentioned that when the Appropriation Bills come before the Committee of the Whole the Senate can hold them up for as long as it likes and question the Ministers for as long as it likes in order to obtain the information that any honourable senator desires. All of this is possible by following the usual procedures available to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view this is a wasteful exercise. It is a bit of political stunting. I do not take the view that Senator Chipp does at all. I believe it is simply political stunting. The Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats could have held up the Sales Tax Amendment Bills. If they were dinkum about putting the Government to the test they would have, on that occasion, returned those Bills to the House of Representatives, as I suggested, and forced the Government to come clean on why it intended to increase the percentage in sales tax on items already subjected to sales tax and why it intended to extend sales tax to other items which included the necessities of life. Both the Democrats and the ALP less than a year ago were prepared, together with myself, to oppose the extension of sales tax to the necessities of life. Why on this occasion are they not prepared to stand the Government up? Actions speak louder than words.

This motion is simply a lot of words when what this country really needs is not words but action to overcome the problems it faces, particularly employment. What good is this motion to the unemployed? All it will do, if passed, is enable the continuation of political point scoring at a time when we have over half a million people unemployed in this land. It is time that political and community leaders came together to attack the problem single-mindedly. It is time that the type of-political point scoring that underlines this motion, which is carried by the Press throughout the length and breadth of Australia, is put aside. It is time that we, as members of parliament, realised that we have a duty to the unemployed and to Australia to give the lead in a combined effort to overcome the problems and not to stir the political pot all the time.

Unemployment is not solely caused by Government policy. Of course the Government's single-minded approach of attacking and bringing down inflation on economic terms has proven to be a failure. Its preoccupation with these economic solutions has not and will not overcome that problem. The problem has social as well as economic aspects. Unless we tackle those aspects, unless we understand that the problem of unemployment at present is simply that more people are seeking paid work than there are jobs available at the same time that automation and technological change are smashing new job opportunities and, indeed, existing jobs, we are failing the unemployed.

We should take every opportunity to urge the Government to take remedial economic measures to overcome the plight of the unemployed. Beyond that we should give the leadership to the calls that have been made for a national conference on employment, which could get down and examine our attitudes to employment. It is my view that the whole problem of the unemployed will not be overcome while we identify work with paid employment and leisure with idleness. We must, as a nation, bring together people and community leaders who will sit down and tackle these problems. Australia would then be able, in a joint way, to tackle unemployment with a plan which would identify the problems and the solutions.

I realise that I have ranged somewhat further than I should have. This matter will be the subject of a notice of motion that I intend to pursue next week. Nevertheless, I raise these points because of the introduction that has been made to this motion and because of the surrounding public arguments. This motion will not achieve anything that cannot be achieved by using the usual procedures available to the Senate. Again I suggest that--

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they?

—I referred to them before. When the Appropriation Bills come before the Senate in the Committee of the Whole we can keep the Ministers here all day and all night if we like to get them to answer the questions.
—On revenue or expenditure?
—On the Appropriation Bills.
—Are you saying that you can question them on revenue?
—On the Appropriation Bills. In the Committee of the Whole we can seek from the Government answers to all of these questions. Unless the Government--
—Look at the Standing Orders.

—The honourable senator has been invited by Senator Chipp to place all these questions in writing to the Government. Unless it is prepared to deliver the goods and to give the information at that time then Senator Chipp has said that the Democrats will hold up the legislation until such time as this information is provided.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect that has been talked about is the possibility of a double dissolution. I could not care less if there were a double dissolution or not. Australia needs an election at this time like it needs a hole in the head. An election would not do anything for the unemployed. It would not do anything for the farm work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would lead to another two-year parliament, of course, because we would go out of alignment.

—That is exactly right. Senator Missen has pointed to another aspect, namely, that it would lead to another two-year parliament and yet another election down the track. It would not do anything to assist the pressing problem of unemployment. I realise that it is in the interests of the Opposition to make every political post a winner. It is in the interests of the Opposition to score political points. Indeed, it may be in the interests of the Opposition at times to allow through the Senate obnoxious legislation, when it could reject such legislation, in order to go to the people who have thus been affected and to say: 'Well, look, you elect us in the forthcoming election and we will remedy that for you'. In my view that is not a proper role for the Senate to adopt. That would turn the Senate into a party political House.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like Senator Walsh, in his reply, to say why the Opposition did not hold up passage of the legislation imposing an increase of 2 1/2 per cent in sales tax right across the board on items that were already subject to sales tax . I would also like him to tell the Senate and the people of Australia why the Labor Party did not oppose the extension of sales tax to items which, on any construction, are necessities of life. Six months ago the Opposition was prepared to do so but now that we are close to a general election-it is election year next year-it is not prepared to do so. The only interpretation one can put on that is that the Labor Party will then go to the people who are affected and say: 'Right, elect us to government and we will remedy that when we become the government'. As I said, that is not a proper role for the Senate. Our role is one of audit and control. Certainly, in order to discharge our responsibilities, we need to have the figures available to us. We have a substantial number of those figures.

It has been quite definitely stated by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick), who is at the table, that he is prepared to provide to the Senate such further figures as are available to his public servants. I for one am prepared to accept that undertaking. If in any way that undertaking is diminished within the next couple of weeks, I will be prepared to join with the Opposition and with the Australian Democrats in holding up legislation in order to ensure that that undertaking given by the Minister is honoured.

I suggest that it would be in the best interests of this nation for the Senate to give a lead in order to overcome the vital problem of unemployment that besets this country. I consider that the proposition put forward by Senator Walsh will not advance that one iota but that, in fact, it is wasting the time of the Senate and creating unnecessary, false expectations in the minds of the public and the Press that something is happening when in fact it is not. Even if this motion were passed, what would happen? It would be simply a political point scoring job and at the end of the day nothing would have happened. Let us not fool people and, far less, ourselves. I believe this motion should be rejected as wasteful and I suggest that the Senate get on with its business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — -In reply-The Senate is debating a motion to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations the accuracy of the revenue estimates previously presented by the Government. For a number of reasons which were given by me when I moved the motion, it is quite apparent that there is a gross error in a number of the individual estimates of the likely revenue collections and also of the aggregate revenue collection. The size of that error is in the vicinity of $1 billion-that is, $1,000m. The Government has stated that it will not support the motion. The Australian Democrats have stated that they will not support the motion. Senator Harradine has stated that he will not support the motion. The attitude of the Government was predictable and predicted. I am disappointed that the Democrats and Senator Harradine have taken the attitude that they have.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons put by the Democrats and Senator Harradine may have marginal relevance to the motions which Senator Button will move shortly but they have no relevance to the motion moved by me, with the possible exception of the point made by Senator Chipp-that is, that the facts have little, if any, influence on the things that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) actually says. The fact is that this motion would have no effect on the passage of the Appropriation Bills, nor would it have any effect on the passage of any other Bill which appropriates and provides for the expenditure of funds. The carrying of this motion would not interfere with Senate business because the proposition we put forward is that the Finance and Government Operations Committee would hold a special hearing next Monday. As I have said, the matter is completely divorced from the Appropriation Bills.

It was also argued by Senator Harradine and Senator Chipp that the same sorts of questions that we want answered can be asked in the Committee of the Whole when the Appropriation Bills are before the Senate. The simple answer to that argument is that questions about revenue cannot be asked or, if they are asked, the Chairman is perfectly entitled to rule them out of order. Equally importantly, nobody in the Senate can directly question public servants in a Committee of the Whole. That can be done only at Estimates committees and at meetings of other committees of the Senate.

Senator Harradine specifically invited or challenged the Australian Labor Party to respond to his question about why we opposed Bills increasing sales taxes in 1981 and did not throw out similar Bills in 1982. There are two reasons: Firstly and most importantly, the 1981 Bills breached a specific undertaking which the Government had previously given. The second reason is that there are and were significant macro-economic differences between the 1981 situation and the 1982 situation.

Senator Carrick, who spoke on behalf of the Government, prevaricated and obfuscated, as is his custom. There was a fundamental contradiction in his argument. He said on the one hand that the information we sought was not available but that if we wanted it, we could get it from the Committee of the Whole by putting questions to the Committee of the Whole and by putting questions with and without notice. What was overlooked in that contradiction that the information is available but is not available is the fact that we cannot directly question public servants. Any figures we seek through the Committee or through questions with or without notice pass through somebody else 's hands. The plain fact is that Senator Carrick cannot be trusted with figures. We saw some excellent examples of that tonight. Either he doctors figures or he does not understand them. I will be charitable; I will accept, at least for the time being, that it is the latter. He is an arithmetic dyslexic.

For example, today he asserted that the Budget deficit estimated by Mr Hayden when he was Treasurer had doubled or trebled by the end of the financial year. He was invited to withdraw that comment, which he declined to do. That suggests that he has no shame either.

The truth is that the deficit did not double or treble. It increased by 50 per cent. The deficit which, on present indications, is almost certain to double is the deficit estimated by this Government in the 1982 Budget. Senator Carrick said that Mr Hayden, in his response to the Budget Speech, had advocated an additional deficit of $1 billion. That much was true. He said that that, added to the deficit estimated by the Government, made precisely $3.3 billion. In fact it makes something less than $2.7 billion. A deficit of, I think, $1,684 billion plus $1 billion makes $2.684 billion and not $3.3 billion, as Senator Carrick asserted.

He also asserted that a deficit of $3.3 billion was what I had forecast this Government would finish with on 30 June 1983. I, in fact, said that this Government, on present indications, would finish with a deficit somewhere between $3.2 billion and $4 billion, which again is far removed from $3.3 billion. Senator Carrick accused me of looking at only some of the figures and deliberately skating around the rest or, even worse, of overlooking the fact that there were other estimates of revenue which I had not mentioned. I explicitly stated that I made no such claim and that I made no claim to having exhaustively gone through the revenue estimates.

He then accused me of, I suppose, trying to fiddle the figures in a minor way by failing to mention that if interest rates fall-I stress the words 'if interest rates fall'-interest payments on Commonwealth borrowings by the Commonmwealth will be lower. If they fall, that is true. However, Senator Carrick, the man who wants to tell all the truth and let it all hang out, failed to mention that, if that happens, it will be partly offset by lower interest payments from the States on money the States owe the Commonwealth. So, in any reduction, the ratios will be of this order: For every dollar that the Commonwealth might save in interest payments on its borrowings because of a general fall in interest rates, it will lose $40 of revenue in interest payments otherwise due from the States on State borrowings from the Commonwealth.

Senator Carrick said that, by the September quarter, company tax had not fallen , contrary to what I had asserted. Again, he could not have been listening to what I said or his mathematical dyslexia prevented him from understanding me. I had drawn attention to the fact that there was a substantial fall in company profits in the second half of the last fiscal year. I said that the Age newspaper had estimated that the effect of that on revenue collections this year would be $600m. I said that for a variety of reasons I believed that that estimate was too high. There are people in the Public Service who have access to information which is not available to the Opposition and which enables them to make a more accurate judgment about complex issues such as that than we are able to make.

This motion seeks to make those people available to the Finance and Government Operations Committee to give what information they have and to subject themselves to questioning by the members of that Committee or by any other honourable senator who chooses to attend. The figures that Senator Sir John Carrick quoted in his reply to my speech are about as reliable as his estimates of the economic viability of the Rundle project. That can be assessed by the capitalised market value of the shares in those partners at the time he was talking it up, which exceeded $1.200m. The last time I looked it had fallen below $400m.

Finally, I want to draw attention to one internal inconsistency in the Estimates as they were originally presented. Statement No. 2 forecast no economic growth, no non-farm gross domestic product growth. Given that people of the age strata to be in the work force increase in number by about 120,000 a year and given that productivity-the output per unit of labour and time- increases, even in bad years, by about one per cent a year, it follows inevitably that if the growth forecast was correct there would be a substantial increase in unemployment. Indeed, it could have been calculated that night, and it was calculated that night, that if the no growth forecast was correct 60,000 more people would qualify for unemployment benefit than the Government had estimated.

That is not a question of being able to make imperfect forecasts. Obviously, nobody's forecasts are precise or infallible. That was an internal inconsistency within the Government's calculations. The Government has now admitted that 65, 000 more people on average will qualify for unemployment benefit this year than it had previously estimated. That increase was implicit in the assumptions which the Government had presented in the Budget Papers but which it refused to acknowledge at that stage. It has partially come clean.

I turn to the problems of forecasting on another matter. I guess that Senator Sir John Carrick rarely gets outside Sydney and probably does not know the growing seasons for the Australian wheat crop, for example. He tried to ridicule the Labor Party for the comments that I had made about the effect of the drought on farmers' provisional tax payments in March next year. He attempted to ridicule the Labor Party because we were saying that one could not tell how serious the drought was in August but one could tell in November. This drought, for the information of Senator Sir John Carrick, who clearly knows little, if anything, about the subject, is primarily a drought in cereal growing areas. I will be more precise still, it is primarily a drought in winter cereal growing areas. In August nobody could tell for certain whether the cereal crop had failed, although there were strong indications that it would. In November we know that it has failed in a great part of Victoria, in the greater part of New South Wales, in a large part of Queensland and in a large part of South Australia. So we do have certain information which was not available, which could not have been available, to anyone in August. In this motion we are asking the Government to ask its own bureaucrats who have access to information to which we do not have access what will be the effects on Government revenue of what is now certain failure of the winter cereal crop in the greater part of Australia's grain growing areas.

Finally, I turn to the recoupment legislation. Very conservatively, as we know, I suggested when I spoke that recoveries from the recoupment legislation would be $100m less than the Government had forecast. Since I said that, I have been told that after the legislation had been through the mangler of the joint party room of the Liberal and National parties for about the fourth time the Bill finally resurfaced in the House of Representatives-it came up from the bottom-of -the-harbour, so to speak-and has been amended in a very significant way. This tough Prime Minister who has cracked down on tax dodgers harder than anyone else has ever done, if we accept his assessment of the facts, has caved in to the tax dodgers. If any of them get their assessments this financial year they will be required to pay 25 per cent of the assessments. They will get 12 months to pay the balance. This is the emasculated legislation which will crack down on these receivers of stolen money, as the Prime Minister described them a couple of months ago. This is the emasculated legislation which finally came out of the mangler of the joint party room of the Liberal and National parties. The Prime Minister has caved in to the tax dodgers and the inevitable result-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a rort.

—It is certainly a partial fraud at this stage. I am willing to chance my arm and predict that in the highly unlikely event of there being an election at the end of this year which returned Malcolm Fraser and of the Liberal Party, dominated by tax cheats as it is, seeing three unimpeded years in power ahead of it, we can forget about getting any of the balance of that money from the tax dodgers. Irrespective of that, the one thing that we now know for certain, because they will pay only 25 per cent of what they are assessed for, if they are ever assessed, is that there will be a loss to revenue of $166m on what the Government had forecast for that item alone. I hope that the other non- government parties and people will change their attitudes, but I am very sad to note that only the Labor Party senators are willing to accept their responsibility as members of this House to perform, in a very meaningful way, their role as members of a House of review and to accept their responsibilities to inform the people of Australia by every means within their disposal as to just what the true position of government finances is now and is likely to be for the rest of this financial year. It is a pity that only the Labor Party is willing to support this motion. That being so, there seems to be no point in calling a division in the Senate on this matter and I do not propose to do so.
