TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move two motions together and to amend the date of report to the Senate contained in both motions from 11 November 1982 to 28 October 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, the particulars of Proposed Expenditure for the Year ending 30 June 1983 of the Department of Primary Industry be referred to Estimates Committee H for further examination and report by 28 October 1982.

That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing orders, the Particulars of Proposed Expenditure for the Year ending 30 June 1983 of the Department of Social Security be referred to Estimates Committee G for further examination and report by 28 October 1982.

As the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) knows, we have been careful to ensure the progress of the Government's program in this October session and, as I told him yesterday, we will do everything to facilitate its program, and dealing with the motions together is a step in that direction. I explain at the beginning the reason for seeking leave to amend the date of report to the Senate. A lot of nervousness has been displayed in this place in the last couple of hours by both political parties and particular honourable senators when their prospective electoral fates have been discussed. I might say that that has involved members of both sides of the chamber. The first point I want to make about the reason for limiting the time in which Estimates committees would be required to report back to the Senate is that when this notice of motion was given yesterday it was the stated intention of the Government that Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) would not even be introduced into the Senate until the week commencing 9 November at the earliest.

TALK.START.PARA: —They changed their minds.

—As Senator McLaren points out with his customary acuteness, the Government has changed its mind on that issue and told us today that the Appropriation Bills would be introduced into the Senate next week, after a fairly dilatory path through the House of Representatives. Of course, if the Government seeks to have the Appropriation Bills passed at an earlier date than was originally intended by the Government, we will do what we can to facilitate that. For that reason, in part, we brought the return date, if I can call it that, forward from 11 November to 26 October.

SPEECH.PARA: Having made that point, I say that it is not relevant because the Appropriation Bills could have been introduced in November, could have been debated and could have been passed notwithstanding the fact that certain items of Estimates were before the two Estimates committees to which these specific matters are referred . I state again, for the record, that it would have been quite in order for the Appropriation Bills to have been debated and dealt with by the Senate notwithstanding that those matters were before the Estimates committees. Unfortunately, there is often a lack of understanding of the procedures in the Senate and there is also a gross capacity to misrepresent the intentions of the Opposition in relation to matters of this kind. The intentions of the Opposition in relation to legislation in the Senate and Budget legislation have been expressed over and over again but are nonetheless continually misrepresented by Ministers in the present Government and particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), who is caught in a web of deception which threatens to engulf him. Accordingly, we did not intend to be misrepresented in respect of this matter, and the amendment to have the committees report at an earlier date has been sought for that purpose. I wanted to make that matter quite clear at the beginning because the Government, as I have said, continually misrepresents those issues. There are many naive young journalists around the place and sometimes they fall for the misrepresentations which are made.

I want to deal with the facts in relation to notice of motion No. 66. This motion seeks to refer to Estimates Committee H the Department of Primary Industry estimates. I say at the beginning that in making that referral to Estimates Committee H the Opposition envisaged a short hearing in which a number of matters, which have been largely dealt with by my colleague Senator Walsh, would be dealt with by that Committee. It is our estimate-it is an estimate shared by others-that the addition to the deficit as a result of the drought will probably be in the order of some $360m. I make the point, which is quite obvious and which was the subject of debate in the previous discussion, that a separate appropriation was passed in relation to the drought relief program and the consequences of the drought. It is proper that that appropriation should go to an Estimates committee. It is proper because of the effects on the Budget. The revised estimates of farm income will have a considerable bearing on the Budget as well. The money which will be available for drought relief was announced after the Budget. In our view it was a somewhat ad hoc, blank cheque type of decision. That will contribute significantly to the size of the deficit. The specific measures were announced on 31 August, two and a half weeks after the Budget. They provide for two main things-a subsidy on the payment of interest rates over 12 per cent, estimated to cost $36m in a full year, and a subsidy on fodder which is estimated to cost $320m in a full year.

Those are the matters which the Opposition wanted referred to the appropriate Estimates committee. It is a function of Estimates committees to examine those items, to determine in a responsible way how they are arrived at and to report to the Senate. That is the exercise in which we were concerned to involve the Senate committee system. We believe that it is a quite proper exercise of the functions of the Senate Estimates committees. For the benefit of honourable senators not prepared to support this motion, I quote from Mr Odgers's book, Australian Senate Practice. In discussing the functions of Estimates committees, he had this to say:
The overriding principle involved is the Senate's-and the people's-right to know how public money is expended . . .

I repeat: 'The overriding principle involved is the Senate's-and the people's- right to know how public money is expended'. I understand the reluctance of Senator Sir John Carrick and the Government to know how public moneys are being expended. After all, they have not been particularly good about collecting public revenue which is owing. I understand, in view of their reluctance to collect revenue which is owing and their continuing reluctance to collect moneys owing from tax evaders, their reluctance to let the public and the Senate know how the people's money is being expended. So I understand the position adopted by the Government in relation to this matter.

I have more difficulty, more concern, about understanding the position of the Australian Democrats in this matter. I thought that if one searched through the volkgeist, the raison d'etre of the Australian Democrats, its position could be found expressed in one slogan, the only slogan they have ever had. It is expressed in the slogan 'keep the bastards honest'. In the words of Mr Odgers, a more circumspect, gentlemanly person perhaps than the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, who coined that slogan, the Senate Estimates committees are concerned about ensuring the people's right to know how public money is expended. The Democrats have interpreted Mr Odgers's words in a somewhat different way. I would have thought, if I might not take too much licence with the slogan of the Australian Democrats, that that is how they interpret their function in this place. Today they have abdicated their function on the basis of a number of specious excuses which amount simply to their paranoid fear of an early election. That is all it amounts to. It is a tragedy to see this once great party committed to that slogan, united behind it as they are united behind nothing else, including what they should do about these motions which are before the Senate. It is a tragedy to see this once great party abandoning its role and its true function here of seeing how public money is being spent by the use of proper procedures of the Senate.

All sorts of reasons are given for that change of position by the Australian Democrats. Such a change is not entirely unusual but all sorts of reasons are given for it. Of course, the reason basic to their change was summed up by Senator Chipp on the PM program tonight when he described the Australian Labor Party as naive. He said the Opposition was naive for moving motions which would bring before the Senate Estimates committees and before the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations fundamental questions of public expenditure and the right of the Australian people to know how their taxes were being spent by this Government, the Australian people already knowing that their taxes are not being gathered in a fair and equitable way by this Government. But they are entitled to know that what is gathered is spent in a fair way.

Senator Chipp, of course, in describing the Labor Party as naive was displaying his own vast experience in this Parliament. He was giving us a friendly jibe, I suppose, by saying we were naive to do anything which might in some ways induce this crazy Prime Minister to call an early election. That, I suppose, is the basis of our naivete. Really, one can be pragmatic, but pragmatism sometimes slips into opportunism and the description of the Labor Party as naive, indeed, the Press release put out by Senator Chipp early today, really I think bears that description.

Senator Chipp has been saying today that he is very concerned, as we know he is concerned, about the plight of the drought sufferers, the unemployed and pensioners who might suffer, he says, if there is any delay in relation to the passing of the Budget in the Senate. I could not agree with him more. They would suffer and that is the last thing we would want to see happen. But, of course, last night the Senate passed, as asked to do yesterday by the Government, the social security legislation. The only way in which the social security legislation, which provides for rises in unemployment and social welfare benefits from 1 November this year, could not have effect is if this Government had in fact virtually gone broke.

One gets to the point where one can believe anything about this Government. Far from being credible it is incredible. It is time the Senate found out in the next week or two whether the Government is broke. If the Government is now broke , it did not know that was the case a week ago. It had no idea about it because at that stage it was putting the Appropriation Bills off until the middle of November. I just remind the Senate and journalists-it is important that they get the facts straight-that last year the Budget was passed in the Senate on 24 November. The year before it was passed on 17 November. The Opposition in this place has given an undertaking to the Leader of the Government in the Senate ( Sir John Carrick) that 11 Bills he sought to have passed by the end of October would be passed. A twelfth Bill was added to the list yesterday. There has been no delay in this Senate in respect of the passing of Government legislation. If the Prime Minister seeks to make the sort of capital out of this situation that Senator Chipp suggests he might, such action would not be in accordance with the facts and it would be naive of the Prime Minister to do so. Of course, Senator Chipp does not trust the Prime Minister-an extraordinary position for the leader of a responsible party like the Australian Democrats to be in. He does not trust him at all and he thinks he might misrepresent the position.

I want to make it quite clear that we want to know about items of government expenditure and about items of revenue because we believe it is the function of the Senate as a House of review to know these things. The Senate and the Australian public have the right to know how this Government is spending its money. These things, of course, are very important to the Government which does not want to let the Australian people have this information. They are very important to the Opposition, the alternative government, because if there were to be an election this year we would want to understand this Budget and the basis on which it is built, and I suspect it is built on sand. We want to understand this Budget because we will be in government next year if an election is held this year. We have to offer responsible alternatives and responsible means of managing the economy of this country.

This is not a matter which concerns the Democrats; it is not a matter which concerns Senator Harradine. The idyllic position in Australian politics enjoyed by the Democrats and Senator Harradine is the capacity to promise everything with the knowledge that they will never have to deliver; the capacity to create all sorts of criticism with the knowledge that they will never have to back them up. That is a very nice position to be in. Of course, it is very important to us as an Opposition-and that is why all Labor senators will be supporting this motion-to know what effect the drought and the drought relief program will have on government expenditure and what effect the drought and the drought relief program and the apparent declining incomes of farmers will have on revenue in 1983. We may have to deal with those problems if the Prime Minister is hell bent on the road to destruction and calls an election this year. We would have to deal with these problems and we ought to be entitled to know whether we are dealing with a government which is built on a foundation of sand or whether there is perhaps a little bit of stiffening in it, although I suspect there is not much. We have moved that the Primary Industry estimates be referred to Senate Estimates Committee H for further consideration so that these matters of fundamental importance which are relevant to the economic management of this country, relevant in terms of determining the issues of what can be done in the very tight and difficult situation, can be dealt with in accordance with the proper functions of the Senate as a House of review. The Committee would then report back to the Senate as a whole.

Of course, it has been suggested in the course of debate that all of these maters can be dealt with in the Committee of the Whole. Senators ought to be familiar with the Standing Orders. The facts of the matter are that in the Committee of the Whole one is allowed under the Standing Orders to ask question about items of appropriation. The Chair can ask to which specific items of appropriation an honourable senator is addressing his remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not mean you will get an answer though, Senator.

—I will come to that in a minute. Senator McLaren is always a bit quicker on his seat than I am. But the fact of the matter is that one is confined by Standing Orders to the types of questions one can ask. It is proper that the Committee of the Whole should have a report from the appropriate Estimates committee on this matter. As Senator McLaren pointed out with his normal perspicacity, it is much more satisfactory and important to get direct answers from public servants, for whom the Opposition has a considerable degree of respect, both for their integrity and their ability, than it is to get the evasive, slippery and waffling sorts of answers one receives from Ministers in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: If one asks a question in here it is like somebody going through a revolving door behind one but coming out in front. Half the time one does not have an idea of what the real answer is and, of course, one is very suspicious that the Minister has no idea either. Senator Townley would understand that on the basis of his numerous questions about postal services, to which no answer is supplied. We would not be so amenable to the course of having these matters dealt with in the Committee of the Whole because we would like to ask public servants what advice they gave about these matters and what estimates they made. We would like to receive honest answers from people whose integrity and ability we respect. That is very important. Estimates committees were established so that public servants could provide such answers and the public could know of those answers.

Notice of Motion No. 67 deals with the referral of the estimates of the Department of Social Security to Senate Estimates Committee G. The subject matter of that referral has already been revealed to a certain extent. It is quite clear that the figures provided in the Budget in relation to the projected level of unemployment were not accurate and were known not to be accurate at the time. If the negative growth rate figure projected in the Budget were an accurate estimate inevitably the unemployment figures would have been much higher. By the time the Budget was brought down on 17 August the actual number of unemployed was already considerably higher than the Budget estimate. I appreciate that that may allow for the fact that the estimates were prepared a month or so before the presentation of the Budget. I do not make any point about that; I just draw attention to the fact that the addition to the deficit now as a result of the estimated cost of the unemployment benefit is of the order of $ 300m.

One could now say that the Budget of the Fraser Government, whose members were so good at lecturing us in years gone by about good housekeeping, about how we had to get in the revenue and be careful with the expenditure and so on, is a reliable estimate of the economic affairs of this country, give or take about $1 ,000m at this stage. That is not pocket money. It is not as much as has been lost to revenue by way of tax evasion but it is still not pocket money. The addition to the unemployment benefit deficit is of the order of $300m. The Budget estimates provided for the unemployment benefit for the financial year 1982-83 were approximately $1 1/2 billion. This estimate was based on an average number of unemployment beneficiaries of 395,000 for the whole of the financial year 1982-83. The number of unemployed in July this year, a month before the Budget, was already 405,000 and in August the figure was 422,000. The latest figure, that for September, is 504,000 unemployed. That represents 7.4 per cent of the work force. It is the highest figure since the Great Depression. More than half a million Australians are unemployed under Fraser Government economic management.

The Treasurer, Mr Howard, even admitted in the Budget that the level of unemployment could rise to 8 per cent next year if this Government is re-elected . According to most estimates that is a conservative figure. In answer to a question asked on Thursday, 14 October, the Treasurer admitted that the sudden deterioration in the job market could mean that unemployment benefit payments will be of the order of $300m above the Budget estimate. The Treasurer said:
It should be stressed that these forecasts are surrounded by considerable uncertainty and, hence, should be regarded as highly tentative.

That was a more circumspect way of using the expression which a former Treasurer , Sir Phillip Lynch, once used when he described the Budget figures as rubbery. The increase in the deficit due to both drought relief funding and the payment of the unemployment benefit are of fundamental concern to the alternative government of this country as the possible future economic managers of a country which is in dire economic straits. We will be the economic managers of this country if, in Senator Chipp's dramatic terms, an election is precipitated by the Prime Minister this year-precipitated, as Senator Chipp put it, against the wishes of the Prime Minister's party and ministerial colleagues, with the possible exception of one.

The Senate is entitled to know how public money is being spent. The Senate is entitled to know how public money is being spent through the appropriate procedures for assessing that-that is, the Estimates committees of the Senate. For those reasons we seek to refer these two items to Estimates Committee G and Estimates Committee H. We expect that those committees could deal with the matters very promptly and that no delays would be involved. If that happens the Senate would be in a position of much greater awareness than it is now of the actual facts in relation to these matters. Those estimates and figures would be given to us by responsible public servants. The result would be that the Senate could have a much more responsible debate about the economic issues facing this country.

As I said, it is sad that the Australian Democrats, for some reason of their own which was hinted at by their absent leader, Senator Chipp, would baulk at the public knowing what the true situation is. I regret that Senator Harradine has seen fit to see this matter in a similar sort of light, although he was a little more ebullient about it all in his call to the nation delivered from the back bench in the Senate, in which he counselled us all to get together and have fun around some of the issues which confront this country rather than discuss these practical matters as to what the Senate should do to obtain this information.

I fully understand the Government's opposition to this proposal. The Government will do anything it can to hide from the people of Australia and the Senate its own dastardly economic mismanagement which becomes more and more apparent every day. It is a logical position for the Fraser Government to take to try to ensure that the public does not have the right to know what the true situation of that economic mismanagement is. I am not in any sense surprised by the Government's attitude in relation to this matter. I commend the two motions to the Senate.

They have had extensive time in which to discuss these and other matters. Those committees have reported to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: As if that were not enough, the Appropriation Bills will be before the Senate in the coming days and an opportunity will then be afforded honourable senators to address these questions. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Against that background, it is apparent that the Labor Party is employing every device possible to spin out the period in this chamber that is devoted to non-legislative business, solely for the purpose of achieving delay. There can be no other purpose than that vexatious purpose in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I invite honourable senators to consider the rhetoric. Tonight we have heard all sorts of rhetoric. Incidentally, Labor Party supporters took offence when I suggested that there was something between the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Labor Party, but tonight there went unchallenged a statement concerning the Liberal Party that was utterly wrong, that is, that it is dominated by tax evaders. That statement was completely and corruptly wrong. Apparently there is to be one kind of sensitivity for the Labor Party and another for everyone else. The Opposition does not like being reminded of its past affiliation with the Painters and Dockers Union, or that the residual owners of the bottom-of-the-harbour companies were painters and dockers, many of whom were, and no doubt still are, financial members of the Labor Party. The Opposition does not like to be reminded of that. The Labor Party has said that the Government is reluctant to collect back taxes. Ours is the Government that is bringing down measures for that purpose. Ours is the Government that set up the Costigan Royal Commission. Ours is the Government that, by its 1980 legislation, outlawed bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. During the term of office of the Whitlam Government, not a single legislative move was made to halt the Curran schemes that were then so rife, and of which the then Government was aware. Against that background we are invited to believe that the Opposition is Simon Pure.

It is asserting that because, since the Budget was presented, things have changed as revealed by the Treasurer (Mr Howard), a special inquiry should be conducted. What about a Treasurer named Hayden who, in October 1975, seven weeks after the Budget was brought down, revealed a little aberration of $786m. Let me repeat his words on that occasion because there was then no plea for a special examination of the circumstances. Seven weeks after his Budget was presented, he revealed an aberration of huge magnitude in these words:

. . . The rate of increase in average weekly earnings is falling back at this stage to a much lower level than we had projected when we prepared the Budget. We prepared the Budget on projections of a 22 per cent increase in average weekly earnings. In fact, they are now at a rate of 17 per cent a year . . . because the increase in AWE is falling, receipts too will be falling . . . if that . . . continues . . . the deficit will be larger than we anticipated when we put the Budget together.

How can the Labor Party say, with any accuracy at all, that it did not know, when it put the Budget together, how average weekly earnings were running? How could the Labor Party be guilty of an aberration which, in the end, amounted to $786m and, having done that, try to claim that it is pure, that it never does these kinds of things, and that if there are drifts at all special inquiries should be conducted.

It is very important to keep these matters basically in mind. Two matters are presented for consideration by a committee. One relates to drought relief, the argument advanced being that the Government should have known of the extent of drought relief and that there ought to have been in the Budget important figures related thereto.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody put that.

—At least it is claimed that there has been a blow-out in the Budget that ought to have been controlled and ought to have been the subject of limitation. The fact is that the main rains that determined the occurrence of the drought were denied this continent in August, September and October. I travel the length and breadth of this continent, in every capacity, far more than does Senator Walsh, and I need no lectures from him on agrarian matters. Had there been rain in those early months, much of the crop could have been saved. Certainly, the pastures could have been saved. I repeat: In the earlier months there could have been, given suitable rain, a great saving of crops. There could have been, and still can be, some saving of pastures, but nobody knows whether there will be rain during the remainder of this month, where it will occur on the continent, how it will affect pastures, or to what extent it will save flocks and stocks. No one knows the extent to which non- breeding flocks and stocks will have to be slaughtered, or how much compensation will be necessary.
—Phlox and stocks are flowers.

—Senator Button, with a grin on his face, is asking that we waste the time of the Senate in order to call together a committee that will try to find out the true cost of the drought. There is not a soul in the whole of Australia who could predict its dimensions. The only question to be asked is as to whether the Opposition agrees with the policy of drought relief that are being proposed. I refer to the specific policies designed to reach out to and aid farmers. If Labor does so agree, over the months ahead it will support whatever is spent on drought relief. Of course, quite clearly, the Opposition does not know, nor does anybody else, how to estimate what the cost will be.

SPEECH.PARA: I want the general public to understand what is being proposed here tonight. We are witnessing a completely phoney set-up-an attempt to waste the time of a committee. There is not a public servant on earth who could tell such a committee, with any accuracy at all, what quantum of money would be spent on drought relief. The only thing that matters is whether this Parliament agrees, with the Government on its drought-relief policies. In that regard, the Labor Party is significantly silent. Let it say whether it agrees with the Government' s policy. If it does, the implication is that drought relief legislation is being delayed through the intervention of this very debate, which has been initiated by the Opposition. It is a preposterous nonsense to ask that a committee should get public servants over here and waste their time in order to ask how much drought relief will cost when not a soul in the whole of Australia knows the answer. This is the party whose Treasurer, Mr Hayden, revealed an aberration of $786m in his own Budget estimates.

The second motion is an even more extravagant motion. The Opposition is saying that something is wrong with the blow-out in the figures for unemployment benefit and, using a nasty phrase, that the figures were known to be inaccurate at the time they were put in the Budget. That is a straight-out reflection on public servants because the fact of the matter is that those figures are provided by public servants. It is on record that that is so. Indeed, that has been made perfectly clear at Estimates committee hearings. To say that the figures were known to be inaccurate is to cast a total aspersion on the public servants.

Let me make it perfectly clear that the figures in the Budget were provided by the departments themselves. They are the figures which have been given already to Estimates committees. Estimates committees provide an opportunity-no doubt honourable senators availed themselves of that opportunity in previous weeks-for honourable senators to ask about figures in the Budget. The public servants would have told them, as has been quite clearly stated, that those figures are their estimates. Let me remind Senator Button of something of which I reminded Senator Walsh this afternoon. It is being argued that the Government knew or ought to have known that there was a gross inaccuracy-an inaccuracy which will mean a 19.1 per cent increment. How does this shape up with the fact that in 1974-75 under the Whitlam Government-in the Hayden era-the number of unemployment benefit recipients was 80 per cent higher than the estimate in the Budget? Did honourable senators opposite then say: 'Let us have an inquiry; stop the world, we want to have an inquiry'? It was 80 per cent higher. Were those figures inaccurate? Did the Whitlam Government and Senator Button know that they were inaccurate at the time? The figures at that time were out by 80 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get those figures?

—They are figures of the Department of the Treasury. They are quite accurate. I will go on because the figures get better. In 1975-76 -the next Budget put forward by the Whitlam Government-the number of unemployment benefit recipients was 60 per cent higher than estimated at Budget time. Was that a known inaccuracy by the Whitlam Government or an aberration?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record of what happens under Labor governments and what happens under non-Labor governments in relation to expenditure on unemployment benefit because in almost every year there have been underestimates. In 1972-73 the expenditure on unemployment and sickness benefits was 34.5 per cent over the estimate. In the following year of 1973-74-a Whitlam Government year-it was 39 per cent. In 1974-75 it was 68.9 per cent. In 1975-76, the last of the Whitlam Budgets, it was 40.5 per cent. In the following years it was 28.2 per cent, 19.7 per cent, 11.3 per cent, minus 7.3 per cent, 3.9 per cent and 12.3 per cent. It is now 19.1 per cent. The Opposition now wants a special committee to inquire into a trend which is demonstrably smaller than it has been over the past decade . It is demonstrably smaller than what has occurred before.

Why does the Opposition want to hold such an inquiry? It wants to do so only because it wants to hold up things. The Senate has heard how the Opposition has engaged in delaying tactics every day and has adopted every kind of technique to try to delay proceedings. It has made all sorts of pious statements to the effect that it will not hold up the Budget. Let me make the situation clear: The moment the Appropriation Bills are passed by the House of Representatives they will be brought in here, which will mean that we will get on to those Bills either late this week or Tuesday of next week. Those Bills will come in here after they have been dealt with in the other place. We have had genuine entreaties by members of the Senate to get the Appropriation Bills in to the Senate. One should not growl about that as they will be here. I hope that considerable progress will be made on them within days of their being introduced in this place.

The fact of the matter is that Senator Button has said rather coyly that there is nothing to stop the Senate committees meeting after the Appropriation Bills have been passed. The advice I have is that Standing Order 36 of the Senate does not imply that nor does any practice of the Senate imply that. It has always been a practice of the Senate to have the reports of the Estimates committees in the Senate before the Senate starts its discussion of the appropriations. It would be ludicrous if we passed Appropriation Bills and then had a negative or critical report on some aspect of the Appropriation Bills. To say it is to demonstrate the nonsense of it. In point of fact the Government hopes that within days the Senate will be getting on to the Appropriation Bills. I am delighted with the comments of the Labor Party and, indeed, of the Democrats that they will facilitate the passage of the Bills. In any case, as I said earlier, during the debate on the Appropriation Bills there is ample time for questions to be directed on this matter.

Let me simply draw these points together. We are debating two motions about whether we ought to reactivate two Estimates committees, those committees having met at length and had unlimited opportunities to have public servants before them to discuss this and any other matter. Those committees have done so and reported to the Senate. The situation is that when the Appropriation Bills are introduced into the Senate the opportunity will be available for further questioning. The situation is that the Government wants the Appropriation Bills passed at a reasonably early date.

I should like to refer to the main points of these two motions. First, I refer to the motion which seeks to find out what the true cost of the drought will be. That is absolute nonsense. Not a single person can estimate what the drought costs will be because no one can tell how the season will progress in the months ahead. No one can tell how the pastures will progress, except Senator Walsh who thinks he is an authority on everything and who, equally, has been proven wrong on occasions. Indeed, he has been consistently wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, for example? Tell me where I have been wrong.
—He goes on with nonsense and interjections all the time. Noise and decibels are no measure at all for good intellectual output. He demonstrates this every day.
—Tell me where I have been wrong.

—Up go the decibels. The Labor Party has one entrenched idea: It is going to try to outshout anybody in the Government who gets up and demonstrably shows up the nonsense of the Opposition. Whenever honourable senators on this side of the chamber are on their feet there is a string of interjections by the Labor Party. The community outside must understand that that kind of disorderly nonsense is no substitute for good honest debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that these two motions are utterly ridiculous and time-wasting. I have shown how much the Labor Party has wasted the time of this Senate over the Budget. It is hollow nonsense and hollow rhetoric for the Labor Party to come forward and say that the Government ought to be collecting taxes as it did nothing when the Curran scheme was hanging like a dead albatross around its neck . Honourable senators opposite are laughing at my comments. The Labor Party knew of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and did nothing about them. Without doubt its branches are riddled by members of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union who, no doubt, are the residua of this scheme. Honourable senators opposite are laughing at my remark but, my goodness, if honourable senators opposite can pin a dead cat on any known Liberal they regard that as good fun indeed. Let them take it as well as give it.

These two motions ought to be rejected. The motion dealing with drought relief should not be referred to a committee because no one could know how much it will cost. I repeat: The only thing that matters is whether the Labor Party and the Democrats agree with the drought relief projects of this Government. There can be no way of calculating it. All that one can know is that if the season gets better the money will be less; if it gets worse there will be a necessity to support the farmers in their peril. Secondly, the unemployment figures were given to us by public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —And then they were doctored by you.

—They are far less inaccurate than at any time of the Whitlam Government, far less to an infinite degree. After an 80 per cent inaccuracy and a 68 per cent inaccuracy during the Whitlam Government the Opposition has the nerve to come in here and say that an aberration of 19 per cent is wrong and that there should be a special investigation. I make it abundantly clear that I resent very much any slur on public servants. I repeat that those figures were provided by public servants in their best endeavours to explain the situation. Again, the smears are there by interjection--
—We have heard two shonky figures from you already.

—Let them shout. The fact of the matter is that the Labor Party had the opportunity day after day in those Estimates committees to ask the public servants these details. They would have got the answer I have given them tonight, that they were the best endeavours of the Public Service at the time. The degree of aberration in those figures shows that it is less today than at almost any time in a decade. On that basis I reject the motions as utter nonsense and as time wasting tactics in the Senate and I ask the Senate to reject them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I reply briefly to some of the comments made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick). The purpose of the two motions which I moved to refer two matters to Estimates committees was simply, in Mr Odgers's words, to ensure that the public knew the truth about how public money was being expended. I moved that the Estimates committee deal with these two matters- basically of drought relief and the estimated cost of unemployment benefits- within a week so that there would be no delay or no capacity for the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to misrepresent the Opposition conduct as delay, which is a different thing, in the passing of the Budget in the Senate. I thought I made that quite clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The defence which the Government offers to this matter was given by Senator Sir John Carrick first of all in relation to drought relief, when he said that it is an impossible exercise to refer it to an Estimates committee because nobody can estimate the cost of drought relief. He said that, his Government having estimated the cost at $356m! In relation to unemployment and the expected increase in the deficit as a result of the payment of increased unemployment benefits, I simply made the point that by the time the Budget was brought down the figures were inaccurate. A month before the Budget was brought down the figures were inaccurate, a month after they were wildly inaccurate and a month later, with the September figures, they were out of control in terms of the estimated costs of unemployment benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you not think we ought to have a higher deficit?

—Yes, we did indeed, but that, with respect, is not the point. If the Government is going to budget for a higher deficit, that is a different thing from not having the capacity to budget for it, which is precisely what I am talking about. The honourable senator's Government did not have the capacity to budget for a higher deficit. On the basis of the information supplied to this Parliament to date it had no idea what the deficit would be, and that is what this is all about. There is a difference between budgeting for a higher deficit and just being incompetent, which is what this Government is. That is the point I am seeking to make. In answer to this allegation Senator Sir John Carrick said 'You cannot estimate drought relief', although the Government has done so.
—He said you cannot be sure.

—I was in here at least. I heard what he said. I know that the honourable senator is a piratical maid of all works on these things. I was here and I understood what he said. The answer to all of this in substance is to advance those two somewhat flimsy arguments which are designed to prevent the Senate committees and the public knowing the answers to these questions. It is a giant subterfuge, a smoke-screen, which Senator Sir John Carrick is very good at making. We were concerned to get these answers from public servants because we have absolute confidence in their ability and integrity in relation to this matter. We wanted honest and frank answers and by the process of going to the Estimates committees we would have got them.
—Do you really think so?
—Honest estimates, I said.
—You have said that word now but--
—They are called Estimates committees. That is where we are seeking to refer these matters to.
—Estimates, not facts.

—Yes, honest and frank estimates. That is all we are concerned to get. I know the honourable senator's reluctance, for a variety of reasons, to have that information, but we do not share it. In answer to this Senator Sir John Carrick goes on with his usual line in saying that in his view the Australian Labor Party Government of 1972 to 1975 was awful and absolutely dreadful. He said: 'You can compare us with them'. He said that in 1975 the deficit blew out by $786m. We are already talking about $1,000m here. Senator Sir John Carrick said: 'If the Fraser Government is a shocking government, our defence is that the Labor Government of 1972 to 1975 was nearly as bad'.
—No, much worse.

—No. With respect, if the honourable senator will listen to what I say-I know he is engaged in conversation-he will realise that the figure that he referred to as the blowout in the deficit of 1975 was $786m. But we are talking about a lot more than that.
—But this is only--

—Do not make excuses, just listen to what I say and try to get it right. The point I was seeking to make-it is clearly a point which is unpalatable to Government senators-was that in answer to the charge that this Government is incompetent in terms of economic management, in terms of its budgetary strategy, the Government said: 'Yes, but the Whitlam Government was just as bad'. I thought that when the present Government assumed power in 1975 its basic case was that it was going to do better.
—And we did.

—Senator Sir John Carrick says that it did. Australia still has the highest inflation rate of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries at the moment, higher interest rates and growing unemployment. This is its record of economic management after seven years. The Minister says: 'We were better'. What Senator Sir John Carrick does in relation to any one of these issues is to give the 'my daddy is a policeman' argument. That shows an absolutely puerile view of the world, if I might say so. I find it pathetic that a man of Senator Sir John Carrick's age and general esteem otherwise-a knight of the realm-says in answer to any criticism that the last Labor Government was as bad or, if he likes, worse. That is not an argument. That is just a childish excuse for an incompetent government, a childish excuse for having the economy of this country in the serious state it is in. All the indices point to that. It is a childish excuse for hiding behind procedures to stop the public from knowing the facts of the Budget.
—Come on, lose graciously.

—There is nothing ungracious about this. I believe all that I am saying. It is immaterial to me whether Senator Missen does or not. I am here as a politician. He was here as a politician in 1975, I remember.
—I was a statesman then.

—He was a great statesman, yes. His coat got caught in the seat when he had to get up. That was his problem as a statesman. The fact is that this is the alibi for the action which the Government is taking on this matter. Only two arguments of substance are involved. I think it is sad that we have these arguments about who is pure and who is less pure because that really has nothing to do with advancing the interests of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other comment which Senator Sir John Carrick made was that the Opposition was trying to spin out legislation for its own purposes. I find that an extraordinary allegation coming from a Minister whose party has not even got the Appropriation Bills through the House of Representatives yet. On a piece of paper given to all honourable senators a few days ago he told us that the Government did not really want to deal with the Appropriation Bills until November; that we would deal with them later in November, together with a number of other miscellaneous Bills. This is the Government which until this point has shown no haste in bringing legislation into the chamber and the Government which knows that the normal course of events is for Appropriation Bills not to be passed until the end of the third week in November. All this stuff about the Opposition's spinning out legislation and the time of the Senate for its own purposes is bunkum.

Of course, what Senator Sir John Carrick is concerned about-he expressed this concern in letters he wrote to people-is that after the Budget only 24 per cent of the Senate's time was devoted to Government Business. Of course it was, because we discovered-the whole of this country discovered-after the Budget that this Government had been miserably and abjectly remiss in collecting the revenue . Any Opposition which failed to draw attention to that fact-any Government senator who failed to be concerned about that fact-should not be here. The report of the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the McCabe-Lafranchi report and others showed that the Government had been losing billions of dollars which it should have collected from the people whom the Prime Minister describes as thieves; the Government has not done so. That is why it lost Government Business at the time of the Budget. As Professor Russell Mathews put it in January:

. . . if the same enthusiasm were to be shown by the Commonwealth for controlling revenue collections as for controlling government expenditures, higher rates of taxation would be unnecessary. . . . I have estimated conservatively that something like 20 per cent of personal income tax nominally payable is being lost to revenue through avoidance and evasion, usually by high- income taxpayers other than wage and salary earners.

He is one of the Government's economic advisers. He said that in January. That is what it is all about. That is why there was not too much Government Business after the Budget; the Government knows that. It is a ridiculous thing to say that in that period the Opposition was spinning out legislation; the legislation was not even here. The Government did not have it ready because it was so concerned at defending its back door against other people in the Liberal Party and outside it. I commend the motions to the Senate. There has been no argument of substance advanced against them.
