TALK.START.PARA: —The Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill provides that farmers who are without cash or liquid assets, such as an income equalisation deposit, who are without reserves of fodder, who are resident in drought declared areas and who are predominantly dependent on farming for their income will be paid as a subsidy 50 per cent of the cost of fodder purchased to keep sheep and cattle alive, with a ceiling of the monthly payment of 80c for sheep and $8 for cattle. It also provides that all farmers who meet the three criteria I stated earlier will have all interest payments on debt on the farm above 12 per cent paid entirely by the Government. I note that there is no means test on the proposition. As the Deputy Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry told Estimates Committee H on 16 September, there is nothing to stop a farmer with net assets of $1m, $5m, $10m, or any figure at all, receiving any amount of money under the terms of the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal has been subject to some criticism-I believe a mounting degree of criticism-from farmers themselves for a variety of reasons, two of which are that farmers have recognised the innate stupidity which underpins it and the inequities within the farming sector. It is a product of what the newly returned prodigal son, Andrew Peacock, once referred to as the manic determination of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to have an election this year before the impending economic collapse became self-evident. The Bill appropriates $356m. That appropriation is a major cause of the deficit blowout which we have been discussing for most of this day. It is also, according to information made available to the Opposition quite recently, a probable under-estimate of the ultimate cost.

I might say, with respect to Senator Sir John Carrick's recent assertions on Senator Button's motions, that matters such as this or indeed any other can be fully investigated in Estimates committees hearings. Estimate Committee H, of which I was a member, had responsibility for this appropriation and other primary industry appropriations. Estimates committees do not work the way that Senator Sir John Carrick suggested they do. For example, on 16 September, at the meeting of Estimates Committee H, a motion was moved that a letter be written to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) regarding two matters, both of which I think have considerable potential to embarrass the Government. That Committee carried a motion that a letter be written to the Minister for Primary Industry about those two matters. The motion was carried because one of the Government senators-and I will not embarrass him by naming him-was not present at the Committee at the time and, therefore, there were three non-government members who carried the motion.

The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Archer, some 26 days later actually got around to writing the letter to the Minister. I regard that as a gross dereliction of duty on the part of Senator Archer and, moreover, I believe it was something that was done quite deliberately with the deliberate intent to help the Minister to avoid replying to those questions before the Appropriation Bills actually came before the Senate.

To return to the drought legislation, the scheme as proposed in the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is riddled with inequities within the farming sector and between the farm and other sectors . It distorts the ground rules of sound farm management and for that reason has quite horrendous implications for the future if it is to be accepted as the norm . Those implications are horrendous on economic and ecological grounds. The provision of a liquidity test as a qualification instead of a means test rewards the improvident and penalises the provident. The Deputy Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry, who appeared before Estimates Committee H on 16 September, acknowledged this. He said:
. . . is potentially subject to a wide variety of abuses.
For all those reasons, I move:
At the end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(a) a limit should be set on the sum that any individual may receive in any one year;
(b) eligibility should be determined by a ceiling on total assets instead of the proposed liquidity test; and
(c) those persons who are predominantly dependent on their farm for their living should be objectively defined'.

Even in happier times, a drought of this magnitude would have had quite significant macroeconomic consequences. Under present conditions, the consequences are much more serious because the drought will compound the damage which has already been done by seven years of Frasernomics. The social loss caused by the drought is real and cannot be avoided. This measure, although statements by Government members sometimes imply otherwise, in no way reduces the social losses, the social cost, of this drought. What it does is affect wealth distribution within Australia. It does nothing to truncate the loss.

On a purely legislative basis, it has set a very bad precedent. The Bill appropriates $356m and enables or empowers the Minister for Primary Industry to make agreements with States; and it says almost nothing else. In effect, it appropriates $356m and allows the Minister to do whatever he likes with it, subject only to the constraints which-and this is subject ultimately to determination by the courts-the courts may rule the explanatory comments in the second reading speech impose on that freedom of action. I might add that of course Bills of this nature which empower Ministers to make agreements with the States for the expenditure of large amounts of money usually-indeed, on every occasion in the past that I can remember-have had appended to them a schedule which at least lays down at least the broad conditions under which the money may be spent. No such schedule is attached to this Bill. The reason for that, of course, is that the legislation was rushed in because the Prime Minister planned to have a premature election.

It was quite apparent at Estimates Committee H that the decision was made at the end of August and that when the legislation was actually in the House the Department of Primary Industry did not really know how it would administer the scheme. The way in which the $356m or the $600m, whichever it turns out to be, was to be administered at the time the Bill was injected was mostly a matter for wide-eyed conjecture. In a country where the media was doing a proper job of informing the public, it is unlikely that any government would have attempted a measure such as this. But I guess the Prime Minister is secure or feels secure in the expectation of continuing media abdication of responsibility to inform the public on matters such as this.

Regarding the inequities within the agricultural sector, I believe that the primary one is that the qualification hinges on a liquidity test and not a means test. There is nothing to stop millionaires getting unlimited amounts of money under the terms of this legislation. Let us consider this anomaly. We have two wheat farmers who had good crops and very high incomes last year. One put $50, 000 into an income equalisation deposit, as the Government recommends he should, as a cash reserve for a bad year. The other mortgaged the farm to buy a luxury unit on the Gold Coast. The first farmer, the farmer who purchased the IED in preparation for the bad year which inevitably comes along sooner or later, will not get the interest or fodder subsidy, at least until he has spent all the IED and any other cash he may have. The second farmer, who mortgaged the farm to buy a unit on the Gold Coast, will qualify for the subsidy.

Let us consider this anomaly between the farm sector and one other, although related to farming. A farm employee is sacked because the crop has failed and he has no work to do at harvest time. He is most unlikely to get another job in the country town in which he resides. He will get from the Government $74 a week unemployment benefit-he will not necessarily get that either-and he might even be vilified by the National Party as a dole bludger. The former employer, who has a high probability of being a member of the National Party, let us assume owns a farm or a farm and non-farm property to the value of $5m. He has 20,000 sheep and a mortgage on the farm totalling $1m at 16 per cent interest. Each month he will get an interest subsidy of $3,332 and a $16,000 fodder subsidy a month. If the drought lasted for a whole year, he would collect $216,000. The Prime Minister has the chutzpah to talk about fairness in government!

Let us look at the question of efficiency. If this legislation is to be taken as establishing the ground rules for farm management in the future, the astute farmer will, firstly, do these things: He will make sure he never has any cash. He will never have a fodder reserve because a farmer can never produce fodder as cheaply as he can get it if the Government pays half the price. Above all, he must never have an income equalisation deposit put away in a year of high income for the next drought because the farmer who does that will not only pay more tax , because the Government rorted the tax laws back in 1977 with averaging and income equalisation deposits, but also disqualify himself from getting the subsidy. The second rule for the astute manager is to buy marginal farm land in drought prone areas because it is cheaper and the returns on capital will be excellent in good years and in bad years the Government will underwrite the loss . The third rule, having bought marginal farm land in drought prone areas, is to overstock it for the same reason-the Government will pick up the losses when the overstocking policy goes bad.

In the second reading speech the Minister said that the scheme was intended especially for breeding stock, to sustain the breeding herd and breeding flocks. However, closer investigation reveals that the payment of the subsidy is not restricted to breeding or potential breeding stock. The full subsidy is available for wethers; that is, sterile males. At current prices, the situation which the Government is sanctioning is very close to this: The Government will encourage farmers to feed $2 worth of readily salable, readily exportable, grain to a sterile male to produce $1 worth of wool. The farmer will be able to cover his expense because he is only paying for half the feed. It is no wonder the wheat price has already been jacked up by about $14 a tonne, as the Australian Financial Review observed today.

Similar pieces of legislation relative to other industries have come before the Senate in the past. One that I particularly remember is the film tax rort of May 1981. I and other members of the Australian Labor Party said at the time that that would destroy the production of quality films in Australia. It is now acknowledged by the film industry that that has happened. Schemes like this will endanger, if not destroy, the efficiency of Australian agriculture. It is a pity that it takes public perceptions a couple of years to catch up with common sense . As I mentioned earlier, the scheme was announced on 31 August more or less off the top of the Prime Minister's head, the source of an assortment of the most blatant economic idiocies that we have seen since this Government has been in power.

At the Estimates Committee meeting on 16 September it was clear that desperate attempts were being made by the Department of Primary Industry to put administrative procedures in place and to restrict abuses and impede the potential cash haemorrhage. The fodder subsidy allows for payment of 50 per cent of the standard price of wheat and for other fodders the subsidy is paid pro rata to their feed values. In the advertisements that have been published I noted one additional anomaly. There appears to be no distinction between cereal hay and lucerne hay, even though there are significant differences in the nutritive value of those two fodders, particularly as the quality of cereal hay is highly variable. The subsidy is not available for payment on straw and yet it is possible that the only difference between straw and hay is that straw does not have a head on it and hay does. The digestibility, the fibre content, the protein level, the digestible energy content and everything else can be almost identical. In fact, it is a continuum and there is no precise line where straw, nutritively speaking, becomes hay.

A ceiling of 80c a sheep and $8 a cattle beast a month has been imposed. It is clear from the Estimates Committee-indeed, it was explicitly stated by Mr Hussey -that nobody would count the sheep because it was not possible. Great reliance is to be placed on a statutory declaration. We had experience of this with a similar scheme in 1977-78-the incentives payments scheme for the beef industry. A couple of hundred fraudulent claims were submited-at least, that many were detected-including one from an officer of the Department of Primary Industry. He was subsequently prosecuted and convicted.

The question arises: What is a sheep? There is no answer. Supposing a farmer has 1,000 ewes which are four months pregnant and five weeks later they are no longer pregnant, they have had lambs. As I read the legislation, if they have a thousand lambs the $800 a month previously payable will become $1,600 a month because there are now, at least ostensibly, 2,000 head of sheep instead of 1,000 . Who is going to count the lambs? The farmers themselves do not know how many lambs they have until some time after birth. In some pastoral areas that time can be anything up to six months or even longer. We should not be surprised if there are some high lambing percentages-at least some very high lambing percentages recorded, whether the lambs are running around or not. Commercial feed lots are excluded but there is no clear definition of what is a commercial feed lot. It is, so officers of the DPI acknowledged at the Estimates committee, partly subjective. Again, great reliance is placed on the statutory declaration, which previous experience has shown is inadequate. It is payable to farmers in drought declared areas. Up to this stage there is no such thing in South Australia as a drought declared area because that has not been the policy followed in South Australia. That is another very fundamental anomaly that obviously was not considered at the very beginning because of the Prime Minister 's desperate haste to get this ill-considered, open-ended scheme out into the electorate because of his manic determination to have a premature election before the public realise that the economy has collapsed.

The fodder component of this legislation-by far the most expensive measure-is to be administered by the States. However, the States do not contribute to the subsidy. So we should not be surprised if the States are less than zealous in properly administering the scheme. We should not be surprised if they adopt a very permissive attitude. It is available, so the second reading speech says, to people predominantly dependent on farming for an income. There is no objective definition of 'predominantly dependent'. As an interesting sidelight, I asked at the Estimates Committee whether an inmate of Long Bay Gaol, H. M. Miller, would qualify for the subsidy. The answer is that, if his property is in a drought declared area and if he does not have too much income from some other source, he will. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) should be able to take the cheques along when he goes to visit him.

It has been said that the subsidy will not be available to Ministers. This shows a surprising degree of sensitivity in a Cabinet which includes the Deputy Prime Minister, who still has a 4 3/4 per cent loan from the Government for the second house that he owns in Canberra which he gave himself 18 years ago. Given a government that is insensitive enough to tolerate that and has chutzpah enough to talk about fairness, I am surprised that it felt obliged to say that Ministers would not qualify. Again at the Estimates committee it was revealed that there is actually no provision built into the legislation to ensure that Ministers do not apply for the subsidy and do not receive it.

What about wheat farmers? Usually wheat farming is conducted in conjunction with stock raising. But the relative importance of the two enterprises varies and occasionally farmers engage in only wheat farming or grain farming. The Australian Wheat Growers Federation said last week that it wanted a 75 per cent subsidy on the cost of seed wheat for next year. Why not? Why not the superphosphate as well? Why not the fuel? After all, they planted a crop which failed; they incurred all the expense of planting a crop which returned no income. Why should they be completely excluded from these provisions when some others within the agricultural sector have been treated so generously?

The Minister for Primary Industry, whose capacity to produce absurd schemes appears to have no limit, subsequently offered to pay the freight backwards and forwards from the eastern States to Western Australia on stock for agistment. The cost of that transport both ways is about $25 a head. If 10 million sheep were sent to Western Australia-5 million sheep would be a more realistic figure of the carrying capacity of the State for the next six months-that would add another $100m to $125m to the cost. Most absurd of all, he offered to pay a $3 slaughter bounty on animals destroyed on the farm. So we have this perfect contradiction-a government subsidising the fodder to keep stock alive and also subsidising the bullets to shoot them, to the extent of $3 a head.

But the implications of that go further. At any time a farmer must have a reasonable assurance that the saleyard price received for stock is at least equal to the cost of sending them to market or the cost of processing them in a meatworks if the farmer is paying for that. In one way or other, of course, that cost is taken out of the price. If the saleyard price is not high enough to cover that somehow or other the cocky gets rid of the stock. But enter Mr Nixon who says to the farmer: 'If you shoot it here I will give you $3 for it'. The price that he has to recover from the saleyard automatically goes up by $3. The consequence of that is that stock which could be profitably processed through a meatworks would be destroyed on farms and an already depressed industry would become marginally more depressed. There would be a social loss of income. By that I mean the whole community would lose income because stock which could be profitably processed would be destroyed on farms. Of course, the cost to the Government and to the taxpayer would also increase. With that sort of ineptitude in the upper echelons of the Fraser Government, that sort of comprehension of how a market economy actually works, it is no wonder the economy is in a state of collapse.

Senator Scott is to speak in this debate. I guess we will get an apologia from him which will seek to convey the impression that a cash transfusion will perform some sort of magic trick that will wipe out the drought and cancel the losses accruing from it. That, of course, is nonsense. There is a macro-loss-a social loss-which cannot be avoided. What this legislation does is to shift the losses around between individuals. It will shift the losses from half the farmers, selected as I have already demonstrated on a rather capricious basis, on to the general community-including other farmers, many of whom may be in a worse financial position than the recipients of this largesse. It has reeking inequity built into it, it massively distorts the rules of sound farm management and it will foster inefficiency and irresponsibility in farm management. As the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry said before the Estimates committee, it is subject to a wide variety of abuses.

I just repeat: What a tragedy that these things which everyone will acknowledge in a couple of years time are not recognised at the time they happen. I just want to make one final point on the question of a liquidity test or an assets test. There is absolutely no correlation between a farmer's indebtedness and his net worth. It is a myth that the farmers who owe money are poor farmers. Indeed, the reverse is more likely to be true. Those who actually have significant mortgages and debts actually also have considerable net assets for the very good reason that nobody lends a lot of money to someone who is broke or about to go broke.

For all those reasons, I urge the Senate to carry the second reading amendment which does not seek to reject the Bill but which just tries to get a bit of common sense through to this Government to set a ceiling on what an individual may receive, to impose an assets test instead of a liquidity test and to define objectively what 'predominantly dependent on farming for their income' means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill is welcomed I think by all senators as a measure which will at least combat in part the problems that are currently occurring within the rural sector of Australia. According to Government figures, an estimated 100,000 farms across Australia have been affected by the present drought. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics figures suggest that the net worth of rural production will be down almost 50 per cent. If this is the case primary production will certainly suffer its worst result for over 25 years. I think the extent of the problem is only now becoming evident to people generally in Australia. The massive disruption caused by the drought will be felt not only now but also in future years. This single problem is a national disaster as great as any we have seen for many years in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has moved in this Bill to give effect to two further subsidies on top of those which are normally in place in relation to drought. It has sought to place a subsidy on interest payments over 12 per cent made by eligible drought declared farmers. I certainly would reiterate the point raised by Senator Walsh about the problems faced in South Australia. I hope that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in his reply will be able to set at rest the minds of South Australian farmers. I was in South Australia last weekend and certainly they expressed some concern about that point. According to figures from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) about only 10,000 out of 100,000 farms will qualify initially for the interest rate subsidy. The Minister has also said that a further 17,000 farms are likely to qualify if the drought lasts for another 12 months. Certainly no one is denying the devastation of the present drought. Even if it continues for another 12 months we are looking at only about a quarter of the drought affected farms being eligible for an interest rate subsidy. This would hardly seem to be a generous proposition certainly in relation to the devastation which is currently affecting rural sectors.

I also raise the point to which Senator Walsh alluded-that is, the relative approach that is being made in relation to grain producers and livestock producers. The Bill has an estimated expenditure for the interest rate subsidy of $36m and an estimated expenditure on the fodder subsidy of $320m. According to statistics of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics the wheat industry is the hardest hit of all farm sectors. Yet the only additional assistance which is available to that sector-the grain grower-is the interest rate subsidy which the grain grower shares with all other primary producers, including the livestock producer. While the fodder subsidy will go only to the livestock producer the interest rate subsidy, or about a tenth of that which is available for the fodder subsidy, must be shared among all areas.

I think that the argument gains further weight if one looks at the gross national farm income. In this area the gross national farm income of crop and grain is about 41 per cent or 42 per cent of total income. The livestock slaughter industry and related products contribute about 58 per cent to the gross national farm income. If that be the case it would seem that the assistance currently being given to the grain grower is disproportionately low compared with the contribution that the industry makes to total farm income. I am certainly aware of the other items which exist in relation to grain growers. What we have operating here is the traditional means test operation, which has always been traditional in the grain growing area in terms of government subsidies, as opposed to the subsidy in terms of the livestock grower which has tended to concentrate on assisting that producer to move cattle, or some other subsidy such as we have here in relation to fodder.

I would hope that by 1982 we could very well have looked in a more close and searching way at those traditional allocations between sectors and possibly attempted to bring back more into focus the enormous contribution that the grain grower does make to the gross national farm income and possibly looked again at a better distribution of assistance across all farm sectors. While Senator Walsh suggested something in a rather disparaging way, it does seem to me that there may not be in the grain growing sector the rather high profile drama which exists in the livestock context. I have visited drought affected areas over the last week. Already the crops have heads on them and they are hardly out of the ground. One can see the enormous amounts of top soil being blown about and piled up across the roads. One cannot but be struck by the fact that those grain growers who, while they may be receiving their payment from the last pool at this point, by next year will be in a situation which will be desperate in the extreme. I believe the interest rate subsidy that has been suggested will not be sufficient to allow many of our grain growers and many of our most productive grain growers to recover.

I now point to a further danger that I see in the Bill. It is a danger about which I am very much concerned. In some ways this Bill may very well militate in the future against a prudent farm manager. I believe that is a matter of concern . It is of concern not only to honourable senators but also to many of the rural lobby groups with which I have spoken about this matter. They have expressed an identical worry about the lack of attention that is being paid in the overall scheme to drought. If one looks at this Bill one will not find a suggestion of the possibility-I do not believe it would be impossible in this Bill so it is not a criticism of the Government-of a farmer who has been prudent in his management being actually assisted in preference to somebody who has not been so prudent. I take the example of two farmers operating identical farms. One farmer had sought by way of investment to increase his fodder holdings, his fodder storage, and to undertake similar activities, whereas the other farmer sought to take his profits and put them into a holiday home. The first farmer would be penalised as against the second farmer. I believe that is not something that anybody would hold up as being needed in this country.

I suggest that what we need to do when we get past this problem-this drought-is very rapidly and from this point onwards to make it very clear that the Government will put in place a national drought insurance scheme. The farmer must be encouraged to put something away for a dry day. I believe subsequent assistance for a dry day ought to be linked with that type of assistance, that type of operation, that the farmers themselves have undertaken. That proposition has been mooted by a number of primary producer organisations. I believe it is one which ought to be applauded by a government which is interested in free enterprise. The facts concerning the problem of drought are quite devastating. In the last century only 22 years have passed completely without drought in this country. In 40 of those years there have been major widespread drought problems. In other words, drought is an inevitability in Australia's primary production cycle. Yet we have no ongoing drought contingency insurance plan.

I believe such a plan ought to be established by seeking a scheme into which the farmer contributes a percentage of his income. Obviously this would take some time to implement. I believe it would take anywhere from seven years to 10 years. The percentage of income paid into a drought insurance scheme may be very low-it may be one per cent or 2 per cent of the farmer's income. That ought to be augmented in every Budget-not just in one Budget, which has caused this enormous economic disruption to the country. In every Budget an allocation ought to be made for drought assistance, whether there be a drought operating at the time or not. That ought to be paid in to support the farmer's contribution from his own income. One hopes that there could be a link to private insurance companies by way of some type of insurance scheme.

The benefit derived would be the promotion of prudent economic management by the farmer. More than that, it would give the farmer complete confidence that when he was affected by drought he would know precisely what he would receive. In other words, the predictability of drought assistance would be of enormous advantage to any producer because it could be built into his overall farm management scheme. If, say, he were a wheat grower he would know precisely what would happen if during the following year, during the winter or late winter, his area was declared to be drought affected. He would know precisely what his income would be and how it could be built into his ongoing scheme.

It seems an utter absurdity that in a country in which, given the facts that I have just mentioned, only 22 years of the past 100 have been drought free, we are still awaiting a comprehensive drought program. I suggest that such a scheme would be welcomed by every primary producer organisation. It would also be welcomed by those who have only a peripheral contact with the land. We would not have the type of economic problem that we currently face because the Government will have to find, out of one annual Budget, such an enormous amount for drought relief.

Primary production suffers from a range of problems, of which this drought relief measure addresses but one. In 1982-83 primary production will be affected by all of the major problems which beset that industry. It will be affected by extreme fluctuations in world markets. It will be affected by the inability of farmers to meet those fluctuations on the world scene. In every primary industry debate in this place people have pointed to the rogue behaviour of the European Economic Community in relation to most international agreements, the latest being in regard to the sugar industry. That merely joins a very long line of problems that primary producers have to face, in terms of international agreements and stability of world markets.

Primary industry is also subject to those national disasters, such as drought, over which it has no control and from which it finds a great deal of difficulty in attempting to recover. If one considers the decreasing number of people on farms one cannot fail to be struck by the fact that unless we introduce a comprehensive policy for primary industry we will not have a viable base upon which to rebuild.

Such a policy must embrace a number of aspects. For example, there must be a national plan, a national commitment to the reintroduction and maintenance of full tax indexation, which is vital to the rural sector. There must be a continuing commitment on the part of all political parties to the existing tax averaging provisions which I believe, from various remarks that have been made in this place by the Labor Party, are currently under threat. Concessional interest rates must be made available on a needs basis. Drought relief such as we have been discussing here should be restructured so as to form part of an ongoing program.

We must also consider the possibility of waiving State expenditure thresholds when a drought extends over more than one financial year. We face a range of problems but a range of solutions is available. However, these are all predicated on one fundamental assumption, that primary production is a vital element in this country's economic future. We believe that the support of primary industry goes a lot further than the primary producer. It must embrace the rural sector in total. As a consequence, we must also consider picking up a number of other aspects, such as updating the zone allowance to a status that looks as though it belongs vaguely to the 1980s instead of the 1940s. It ought to be based on social grounds, at a local government level, rather than on the absurd lines that currently are drawn on a map.

The Government should consider, as a matter of urgency, the removal of the sales tax on the freight component of goods. That proposal is currently before the Senate in the form of a private member's Bill introduced by the Australian Democrats. The Government ought to be attempting to do more than it has hitherto to ensure that the fuel equalisation scheme actually works in country areas. It seems to be working fairly well in the cities, but what use that is in terms of having a fuel equalisation scheme I do not know. Everyone knows that the differentials are way beyond those allowed under the legislation, yet very little effort seems to be exerted to bring the position back into line with the statutory obligation set down by this Parliament.

Also, I believe that the rural sector has a just claim to equity, when compared with the urban sector, in relation to the services that are offered by government. That is probably one of the most telling differences that one notes when one goes into the more remote areas of our States. One finds entire populations without access to the normal services that we expect in a city, as something to which we are all entitled. I refer here not only to high profile facilities such as colleges of advanced education and universities but to such ordinary matters as having a pharmacy, a dentist or doctor, having reasonable medical care and being able to send one's children to a local school that extends beyond the primary or grade 10 level. Such facilities are of vital concern to country dwellers. They are of vital importance to the towns in the rural sector and it is the towns that now are suffering more than ever the effects of drought.

The support that the Government has offered under this Bill will go a long way to assist not only primary producers but also, in turn, country towns. We must always remember that the majority of people in the rural sector of Australia are not primary producers but rather people who provide services for primary producers. Therefore, it is extremely important to bear in mind that when we are talking about the effects of drought we are talking about the economies of most of the small towns of this country. The small shopkeeper, the local bank, the local producer of farm machinery are now all feeling the pinch. We look around us and find company after company going bankrupt because they service the primary sector.

Before we come out of this drought the country will pay dearly. I believe that if we are to gain anything from this drought-and surely we ought to gain something from it-it will be a hard learned lesson. That lesson will cost this country dear. One lesson which should come out of this experience is that drought is an inevitable part of Australia's climatic conditions. Because of the inevitability of droughts, governments have a consequent obligation to plan and to allocate money every year to make sure that we are able to cushion the effects of droughts in future in a more effective and practical way.

I commend the Government for introducing this Bill and for taking further the drought measures which are available under other legislation. The Australian Democrats will support the Government in any further measures that it takes to ensure that we have a viable primary production sector when this drought is over .

I refer now to the amendment which has been moved by the Opposition. The Democrats see some merit in the points raised in the motion moved by Senator Walsh, particularly the second point. I have put forward the idea that we might be supporting or at least inclining towards bad primary production management if the Government's intentions were to continue like operations in the future. I hope that the Minister will be able to refer to that item and possibly make sure that no impression is created that it is a good idea in future not to engage in prudent farm management schemes. The Democrats will not support that part of the amendment. I do not think it adds anythings to the current debate.

The first point in the amendment seeks an imposition which, I believe, is far more arbitrary than anything that the Government has suggested. The Government's limitations relate to need. It seems to me that that is where the limitations ought be put. It seems to me rather absurd to put a limitation on an individual. For example, in relation to the fodder subsidy, surely the limitation ought to be where the Government has placed it, that is, on the number of cattle, sheep or whatever the item is. That seems to me to be the 'in need' limitation and not the limitation on an individual. It is not the intention of the Democrats to support the amendment that the Australian Labor Party has moved to the second reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to note that Senator Macklin has indicated that the Australian Democrats support the Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill 1982. Senator Macklin indicated that he does not support the somewhat innocuous-perhaps in some ways it is insulting- amendment that has been moved by the Australian Labor Party. Senator Macklin spent a great deal of time talking about the problem of drought in this country. He emphasised the fact that Australia is a drought prone land and, of course, it is; it is the driest continent on earth. He spent some time also discussing the possibilities of establishing some sort of drought insurance. That, of course, has been a concern of producer organisations and, indeed, of the Government parties for many years. It is not the most simple proposal to establish.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that Senator Macklin referred to purdent economic management by the farmer. Senator Walsh in his usual fashion was intent on insulting the farming community on most standpoints. The inference by Senator Macklin was that prudent economic management was hard to find. Of course, the same was inferred in the remarks of Senator Walsh. I do not believe that the average Australian farmer lacks prudent economic management. When farmers have been confronted, as a great number of farmers in this country have been confronted, with droughts which have lasted three or four years and sometimes consecutively, they have little capacity to show a great deal of prudence. All that sort of inference shows is a complete lack of understanding of the drought circumstance that confronts Australia today.

Tonight the Senate is discussing the Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill 1982. In view of the remarks of Senator Walsh and, to a very much lesser degree, the remarks of Senator Macklin, I think it is important to understand why this circumstance is so extraordinarily serious. It has been implied that the problems facing farmers could have been avoided in some way by prudent management. The drought that confronts this country today is serious not only because of its severity wherever it occurs but also because of its physical extent.

The drought covers a very significant part of Queensland, probably 90 per cent of New South Wales, a significant part of Victoria and most of South Australia. The consequence of that alone is that there is no area of relief. There is no agistment. Very little conserved fodder is left. This drought is the culmination of three to four years of virtual drought in a very significant part of Australia. We are confronted, consequently, with circumstances that have never been experienced in this dry land before. I think that should be recognised by those who tend to say that people should be more prudent.

The legislation before us seeks, first, to subsidise interest payments above 12 per cent when the liquid assets of the producer concerned have become so low that they represent no more than 12 per cent of his total farming debt. The second element of this legislation is to establish a fodder subsidy. Both of these proposals are funded totally by the Commonwealth Government. The interest subsidy, of course, is administered by the Commonwealth. The fodder subsidy is a 50 per cent subsidy on the purchase of fodder for drought affected sheep and cattle in drought declared areas of Australia. That is a very generous subsidy but, indeed, a very necessary subsidy.

The object of those two elements which are the basis of this legislation is, in the first place, simply to keep farmers on their properties, to keep operators on the land. Incidentally, they know the land quite well and can operate it effectively, given any sort of climatic advantage. In the second place, the object is to retain a significant number of breeding stock. The recovery-and recovery there will be from this drought-will be relevant in no small degree to the amount and quality of breeding stock that is able to survive the rigours of this period.

That reminds me of one other matter that was mentioned in passing by, I think, Senator Walsh. He referred somewhat disparagingly-of course, that is nothing to remark on-to the subsidy being available for wethers. Of course, perhaps in the long term they are not as significant to recovery; but I presume that Senator Walsh understands that the wethers in the Australian flock are extremely significant in establishing a price base for the whole of the Australian sheep industry. Consequently, it is reasonable to assume that the subsidy should be available for them also. It might be relevant to remind the Senate that the subsidy, which is spoken of as if it is some massive contribution per sheep, an enormous gift, in fact represents about five ounces of wheat per day per head of sheep. That is a minimum subsistence rate-in other words, a survival rate. So it is not enormously generous in that sense.

The statistical extent of this drought has been mentioned many times. I will move very quickly over it. It extends to practically two-thirds of the properties in rural Australia, and that is a mighty big percentage. It concerns a drop in cash flow, in income, to rural Australia of an estimated $1.3 billion at the moment. It could well be significantly more than that. The cash flow in extra-metropolitan New South Wales-the worst affected State-is likely to be in the vicinity of 70 per cent less than that of a year ago. That sort of circumstance extended to the whole community-the villages, the towns and provincial cities of this country-gives honourable senators some idea of the extreme severity of the circumstances about which this legislation is drawn. It is interesting also to remember that the cash flow in the rural community comes virtually once a year. If that cash flow dries up to that extraordinary extent of 70 per cent one can look to no further significant cash flow for 12 to 15 months. That, in itself, emphasises again the severity of the situation.

One thing that follows from that discussion is that this drought has highlighted, more than probably any other thing at any other time, the interdependence of the whole Australian community and in particular the community that lives in extra-metropolitan Australia, because today in talking about farmers as agriculturalists and graziers we are talking about a mere 6 per cent of the Australian population. It was more like 25 per cent 50 years ago. Today it is 6 per cent. But that 6 per cent produces far more per capita than any other rural, agricultural or pastoral community in the world. They are the most efficient producers per capita in the world today, in spite of the insults that are hurled upon them from time to time. They have reduced themselves to that number and increased their efficiency and productivity for a number of reasons, such as the introduction of chemical farming, fertilisers and massive machinery and as a result of research-very often research and understanding that finds its beginning in the farming community. These and a whole host of other reasons, such as new cultivation methods, a capacity to handle and maintain moisture in the soil, prove that point. Australians are the leaders in the world in dry land farming. They even go to the Middle East, to the deserts of the world, and teach the people there how to farm, how to conserve moisture, how to develop other plants and how to irrigate. These people are not really inefficient, messers or bad managers; they just live in an extraordinarily dry country which, in the last five-year period, has been significantly drier than it has ever been.

The figure of 6 per cent that I referred to is relevant in that something like 3,500,000 to 4 million Australians are virtually directly dependent upon those farmers and agriculturalists who make up that figure. I refer to a whole range of industrial and commercial activity. I refer to people who are involved in the transport industry, the chemical industry, the fertiliser industry and aerial agriculture. The advent of the drought in New South Wales will cost the New South Wales Government railways something like $100m to $120m this year in loss of revenue. The situation of those farmers is of relevance to the vast range of machinery producers of the service industry. I could continue right across the board. The point is sufficiently made by saying that, although only 6 per cent are directly concerned with this legislation and what it seeks to do, 3.5 million to 4 million Australians are in no small degree dependent on the success of the industry which is under threat today.

I will refer in a small amount of detail to the interest and fodder subsidies. The difficulty with establishing an amount referable to the interest and fodder subsidies is quite obvious because no one knows what it will be. I was somewhat surprised when Senator Walsh, in his opening remarks, referred to the amount of $356m as a significant contribution to the alleged blowout of this year's Budget . Of course, it is a significant contribution. It is a contribution that cannot be estimated accurately. It could not be foreseen two, three or four months ago. In my view and in the Government's view it is a contribution that has to be made . Does Senator Walsh suggest that it is too expensive and it might be better to let the stock die or let the people leave the land? A government has to meet its responsibilities and some of those responsibilities are not easy to quantify, if they can be quantified at all, before some point of conclusion is reached. The point of conclusion in this area is very hard to judge indeed.

I refer again to the interest payment subsidy. I make the point-it is an important matter-that we recognise the very strict eligibility criteria that apply to the interest subsidy over 12 per cent. As I explained earlier, when there are cash reserves equal to no more than 12 per cent of the total debt, then and only then will the subsidy apply. The cash reserves concern themselves with cash in the bank, term deposits, income equalisation deposits, stocks and shares, governments bonds and so on. The debt, of course, has to be for the purpose of primary production. I recall that in relation to this subsidy Senator Walsh insinuated that people make statutory declarations lightly, as though they do not mean very much and they are not much of a guideline. I do not believe that is the way statutory declarations are viewed either by individuals or by the nation as a whole. Statutory declarations are necessary in the case of the interest subsidy and in the case of seeking a subsidy for fodder. Another interesting view-this was also promoted by Senator Walsh-was that there was virtually little difference between the value of straw and of hay. It always amazes me that people strip their crops and do not keep the straw for fodder. They do not seem to do that.

I must press on to the fodder subsidy which is based on 80c per sheep per month and $8 per head of cattle per month. I think I mentioned earlier in the course of my remarks that that 80c per sheep per month is an amount which will enable sheep to survive over a significant period-3 or 4 months-depending on whether there is anything else for them to eat besides the grain. If there is nothing else they will not survive for very long. But, indeed, it is a subsistence level of diet and has to be viewed as such. The manner of claiming subsidy on other forms of fodder has been clearly established. Wheat is taken as having the basic nutritive value and the other forms of fodder will represent a percentage of the value of wheat in a nutritive sense. Consequently, there is very little room for any significant abuse if people are bent on abusing the system. I believe that the great majority of people have no interest in abusing the system. They are keen to survive and to keep their assets, to keep their stock fit and alive. But if indeed they seek to abuse the system, the chances are mighty few. The guidelines and criteria are responsible and significant.

I recall that Senator Walsh made some fairly slighting remarks about the possibility of establishing a slaughter subsidy. An amount has not been determined, but just for the sake of argument, if it were $3, it would not be a total waste or a gift. The significant thing is that the establishment of that sort of slaughter subsidy would put a base in a market-place. That is what the subsidy would do. For instance, it would stop processors from moving into the market-place and buying stock at a give-away price of a few cents. At least with a $3 slaughter subsidy there will be a base in the market-place and a stop to any form of needless slaughter. That is the important thing to remember concerning any slaughter subsidy criticism.

There has been an amount of criticism on this legislation from some quarters, such as from the Australian Labor Party spokesman and a few others, that is seeks to provide shelter for the poor operator; that it will be chiefly a boon to the poor operator; that he should not really be the beneficiary; that the prudent operator-that lovely word-should be the beneficiary. Basically that is as it will be because one must look at the people who we describe somewhat glibly as poor operators and ask ourselves in truth: Are they in fact poor operators? I suggest that some of the people referred to may be relatively young in their industry. They could have just made a relatively recent advent into the industry. They would clearly carry very significant debt structures compared with people who had been in the industry for many years and consequently they would need a great deal of help. But the help would be needed not because they were poor operators but merely because they did not have the opportunity to develop from that point of entry into their industry where they carried very significant debt and where climatic circumstances could make that an extreme embarrassment.

Mention has to be made of the fact that some of the people involved would be subject to unfortunate circumstances. I have already mentioned one in another context. They could well be subject, as indeed hundreds and thousands are subject, to a circumstance in which they are not looking at one drought year or a droughty six months; they are looking at literally three or four years of drought. It is hardly a fair basis for condemnation to say that they are inefficient or imprudent when in fact they have suffered a continuing drought. They could be in a difficult situation for health reasons or, indeed, they could have been subjected to pests and disease in the progress of their industries. There are one or two further matters that concern me in this debate but at this point I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

This is an omnibus Bill to amend the National Health Act, the Health Insurance Act and the Health Insurance Commission Act.

By the Bill the Government seeks to give effect to a number of measures foreshadowed by the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security. These measures will further demonstrate the Government's concern for those persons and families in our community who are in special need.

The Bill would implement a major expansion of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. The Government proposes to make available drugs and medicinal preparations on the pharmaceutical benefits schedule at 50% of the general contribution rate to a larger number of persons in need who presently pay the full contribution rate.

The Bill would also make a number of amendments to pensioner health benefits entitlements to reflect the significant improvements to our welfare system that are included in the recent social security legislation amendments.
The opportunity has been taken to make some important changes to the health insurance arrangements.
Let me now deal in detail with the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
The new patient contribution arrangements for pharmaceutical benefits will involve a three-tier system of contribution in place of the present two-tier system.

Pensioners (including supporting parent beneficiaries) who hold pensioner health benefit cards and sickness beneficiaries who hold health benefit cards, and their dependants, will continue to obtain pharmaceutical benefits without charge.

Health care card holders and those on social security pensions (including the supporting parent benefit) or service pensions who, because of income, are not entitled to a pensioner health benefit card will be classed as concessional beneficiaries. As honourable senators will recall, under arrangements introduced from September last year, low income persons, unemployment and special beneficiaries meeting the income test and all migrants during their first six months residence in Australia are entitled to a health care card. By virtue of clause 27 of the Bill such concessional beneficiaries and their dependants will be entitled to pharmaceutical benefits at the reduced contribution rate of $2 per benefit item. About one and a quarter million people-who under existing arrangements are required to pay the full patient contribution-will be assisted by this initiative. The rest of the community will pay a patient contribution of $4 per benefit item, an increase of 80 cents.
These new arrangements would come into operation on 1 January 1983.
It is estimated that the changes could result in a net increase in Government spending in 1982-83 of about $2.8m and about $7m in a full year.

Provision is made in clause 26 of the Bill for the patient or an agent to be responsible for the establishment of the appropriate entitlement-that is whether pharmaceutical benefits are to be supplied free of charge or for a $2 concessional patient contribution. At the present time medical practitioners and participating dental practitioners are the only persons allowed to endorse pensioner entitlement numbers on pharmaceutical benefit prescriptions. From 1 January 1983 this will no longer be the case. The patient or his agent will establish the relevant entitlement by completing a declaration that will be printed on the prescription form.

This new arrangement would ensure that patients receive their appropriate entitlements in respect of patient contribution concessions for their pharmaceutical benefits. In addition the new arrangement should overcome problems met by patients and chemists when entitlement numbers are omitted from their prescriptions by the prescriber.
Mr President, I would like now to turn to the amendments proposed in this Bill to effect other changes already announced by the Minister for Social Security.

Clause 5 of the Bill would amend the Health Insurance Act to assist invalid pensioners and persons in receipt of a sheltered employment allowance who want to re-enter the workforce. From 1 January 1983 any such person who loses entitlement to these social security payments because he or she commences open employment would be entitled to a heatlh care card for twelve months free of income test.
Mr President, it might be worthwhile if I take this opportunity to remind honourable senators of the more significant benefits that are available to persons who have a health care card. These are:
The provision, with the agreement of the medical practitioner, of scheduled medical service free of charge;
In other cases a Commonwealth medical benefit of 85 per cent of the schedule fee for medical services or the schedule fee less $5.00 whichever is the greater , without the need to insure;
Free outpatient treatment and free inpatient treatment as public patients in shared wards of public hospitals;
The provision of optometrical consultation services free of charge; and

It has always been of major concern to invalid pensioners that if they attempted to return to work they would lose their fringe benefit entitlement. The health care card entitlement will go a long way towards removing this concern and, it is hoped, encourage some invalid pensioners to re-enter the workforce. I am sure that all senators will welcome this initiative.

I would now like to draw honourable senators' attention to the extension of full fringe benefit entitlement, subject to an income test, to persons in receipt of the proposed rehabilitation allowance. This new form of income maintenance to be paid under the Social Security Act will be introduced from 1 March 1983 for people who undertake a rehabilitation program with the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service. As honourable senators will be aware from the social security legislation amendments the allowance will be available at not less than the rate and under the same conditions as the invalid pension.

Clauses 4 and 14 of the Bill would extend the definition of eligible pensioner in the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act to include persons receiving the rehabilitiation allowance. Such persons would thus receive a pensioner health benefit card, subject of course, to the fringe benefit income test.

Perhaps at this stage I can remind honourable senators of the benefits available from the Federal Government for persons who hold a pensioner health benefit card or health benefit card. These persons are entitled to:
The provision, with the agreement of the medical practitioner, of scheduled medical services free of charge;
in other cases a commonwealth medical benefit of 85 per cent of the scheduled free for medical services or the schedule fee less $5.00 whichever is the greater, without the need to insure;
fee outpatient treatment and free inpatient treatment as public patients in shared wards of public hospitals;
the provision of optometrical consultation services free of charge;
free pharmaceutical benefits;
free hearing aids and batteries;
telephone and postal concessions; and
travel concessions with Australian National Railways and for sea transport with the Australian National Line.

Mr President, the Bill would also provide that persons who receive the family income supplement or the mobility allowance introduced by the social security legislation amendments will not lose their eligibility for a health care card because of this additional income.

The amendment to the Health Insurance Act will ensure that any family income supplement or mobility allowance that a person receives would not be taken into account when assessing eligibility for the health care card.
Mr President, I now turn to some important changes relating to health insurance arrangements.

First, I draw the attention of the Senate to the measures in Clauses 23 and 43 of the Bill. These measures would preclude the application by any State or Territory of any special levies on registered health insurance organisations. I am sure that honourable senators will be aware of the legislation passed recently by the Victorian Parliament which imposes a levy on health insurance organisations in that State. The levy, at the rate of 80 cents per week per family contributor and 40 cents per week per single contributor for basic hospital tables, has been imposed since 1 August 1982. The levy is intended to finance outpatient services provided to insured persons in Victoria. Separate charges are not raised by the Victorian public hospitals for these persons.

The Victorian Government introduced the levy because of alleged difficulties in collecting outpatient revenue. The levy arangement has a number of undesirable implications which, from the Federal Government's viewpoint, make it unacceptable.

Victoria has used a broad legislative provision to solve an administrative or management problem in its hospitals. The arrangement cuts across the Federal Government's ''user pays'' policy for health services. The levy is estimated to produce revenue in excess of that indicated by utilisation of outpatient facilities and thus contributors to Victorian health funds are paying more than they need for health insurance. The Bill would preclude the operation of the Victorian levy from the date of royal assent of this Bill and preclude the introduction of similar levies for inpatient and outpatient services in any State or Territory. The Bill would re-affirm the Federal Government's responsiblity in the area of health insurance, including its role to protect the insured public and the taxpayer.
The proposed amendments do not affect the basic responsibility of the States and the Northern Territory to determine charges in public hospitals.

Secondly, I would like to draw honourable senators' attention to provisions in the Bill relating to the scrutiny of any directions a Minister may give a registered organisation concerning its management practices. The purpose of the Bill is to make provision for the financing of part of the prospective 1982-83 Budget deficit. As is frequently the case, the prospective deficit gives rise to the probability that calls on the Consolidated Revenue Fund will exceed moneys legally available to that fund, even after use of various legislative provisions to charge certain expenditures to the Loan Fund rather than the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Honourable senators will be aware that expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot validly exceed moneys available to that Fund. Thus, for many years, successive governments have introduced legislation in the form of a Loan Bill of the type I am now presenting, for the purpose of funding defence expenditure out of the Loan Fund.

The Treasurer announced in his Budget Speech for 1982-83 that the prospective overall budget deficit for this year was estimated to be $1674 million. At this stage of the financial year, there are two areas where the need for additional outlays has become apparent. One relates to expenditure on the new drought relief measures which, on the basis of present tentative estimates, could cost some $350 million in 1982-83.

It has also become necessary to revise the Budget estimate of expenditure on unemployment benefits. While there is a good deal of uncertainty surrounding such estimates, present indications are that expenditure could be some $300 million greater than expected at Budget time.
Particularly given these sizeable additions to the budget estimates of outlays and hence of the deficit it will be necessary for some defence expenditures to be financed from the Loan Fund.

This Bill will therefore authorise borrowings for defence purposes-both under the Department of Defence and the Department of Defence Support-to enable defence expenditure, which would normally be met from Consolidated Revenue Fund, to be met instead from the Loan Fund.

I should make it clear, however, that the Bill does not authorise any defence or other expenditures additional to those which have already been authorized by Parliament in Supply Act (No. 1) 1982-83 or which will subsequently be authorised in Appropriation Acts for this financial year.
In this regard I draw the attention of honourable senators to clause 8 of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83, which makes that Bill subject to the provisions of the proposed Loan Act.

The Bill includes a specific limit to the amount of any borrowings that may be undertaken. That limit is $1500 million which amount the Government considers reasonable to meet the prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Kelvinator Australia Ltd: Plant Closure-South Australian Election: Mr Alan Carroll-Community Youth Support Scheme: Maryborough, Queensland-MacLaren Clan: Annual General Meeting

PROCTEXT.PARA: Kelvinator Australia Ltd: Plant Closure-South Australian Election: Mr Alan Carroll-Community Youth Support Scheme: Maryborough, Queensland-MacLaren Clan: Annual General Meeting

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question :

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to raise a matter which was the subject of a question I put to Senator Chaney earlier today. It concerns the jobs of 400 workers at the Kelvinator plant in South Australia which are under threat because of the massive increase in the imports of room air conditioners into Australia over the last three years. In August of this year the Temporary Assistance Authority was requested to investigate and report on whether it was necessary for urgent action to be taken to provide assistance to the air conditioning machine manufacturing industry in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Kelvinator Australia Ltd, the principal manufacturer of room air conditioners in Australia, was seeking a five per cent increase in the tariff level together with an additional five per cent penalty tariff for imports in excess of 90,000 units. In its application to the Temporary Assistance Authority it was supported by the United Trades and Labor Council in South Australia which has members of 12 of its affiliated unions employed in the manufacture of room air conditioners at the Kelvinator plant in Adelaide. The company and the unions have both argued that Kelvinator is facing a major threat from imports of room air conditioners. Figures I have seen certainly show this to be the case.

Between 1978-79 and 1981-82 imports of room air conditioners increased from 72, 449 units to just over 187,000 units-an increase of 158 per cent. It's interesting to note that imports from Japan increased in that time from around 22,000 units to 87,000 units-an increase of a massive 400 per cent. Meanwhile total retail sales of room air conditioners have increased by only 58 per cent between 1978-79 and 1981-82. This has meant that potential local production has actually fallen from 64,500 units in 1978-79 to only 35,000 units last year. In other words the market share occupied by imports has risen from 53 per cent to 86 per cent in the last 3 years.

If imports increase in 1982-83 at the same rate as they have increased in previous years total imports this year could be as high as 268,000 units, well above the expected total sales figure of 193,000 units. Clearly this shows that local production would be whittled down to nothing. Even if imports stayed at last year's level the potential local production for 1982-83 would be down to 6, 000 units, one-fifth of what it was last year. From all this, it is quite clear that the jobs of workers involved in the manufacture of room air conditioners in South Australia are being jeopardised by cheap imports. Simply this means that 400 workers in South Australia are threatened with retrenchment unless something is done to stop the flood of imports.

Kelvinator has categorically stated that 400 jobs will go if some form of temporary assistance is not received from the Federal Government. These 400 workers would be in addition to the 279 workers retrenched by Kelvinator earlier this year and in addition to the 300 workers in another section of the plant who were told by the company last week either to accept a four day week or lose their jobs altogether. This is a very grave and serious matter indeed. I know the recommendations of the Temporary Assistance Authority are now before Cabinet and I want to urge all Government Ministers-particularly Senator Messner who is the only South Australian Minister in this place-to do their utmost to ensure that Kelvinator is given the temporary assistance it requires.

The last thing we need in South Australia at the moment is another 400 retrenchments, especially just before Christmas. South Australia already has the highest unemployment on the mainland and a youth unemployment rate of 29 per cent. We have seen something like 1,500 retrenchments in South Australia's manufacturing industries since January 1982 and there are rumours that General Motors-Holden's Ltd will put off more workers after the State election.

What worries me, as far as the Kelvinator situation is concerned, is the precedent set by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd case. When that company recently asked for special temporary assistance the Government refused it and we will no doubt see the end result of that over the next few months. No doubt the decision was reached after pressure was applied to Cabinet from the so-called dries or free marketeers on the Government benches.

I hope for the sake of South Australia that history will not repeat itself. I hope the Government does not wait until after the State election because if it does we all know what that will mean. It certainly would not want to jeopardise 400 jobs before a State election. I will not keep the Senate much longer. I just want to say in conclusion that I hope common sense will prevail and that the Cabinet will put the jobs and livelihood of 400 workers and their families before the principles of the Liberal Party dries.

The other point I raise tonight relates to international flights to Adelaide, which will commence on 2 November. The first flight will arrive in Adelaide on that date. In fact it was to be a grand scenario for the South Australian Premier on that day. Premier Tonkin was to arrive from Singapore on the first flight and, as he would have calculated, make major political impact on the State. TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly on the adjournment tonight to answer the many queries which have been directed to me in the course of the day as to my reason for wearing a tie today.
