SPEECH.PARA: I want to say to the Senate that we are a warlike clan and I wear this tie not only in memory of the MacLarens, my forebears, and in recognition of the fact that the annual gathering of the clan will be held in Edinburgh at about this time, but also to signify to the Liberal Party that I am doing battle with it in South Australia for the next three weeks. I am sure that, as MacLarens have done in the past, we will win that battle and the party that I support will be in government after 6 November. I am sure that will not be a very happy day for Senator Chaney but it will be a very happy day for me and most of the MacLarens.

I am sad to say that some of them are not supporters of the Labor Party but most of the MacLarens whom I know are very loyal to the clan. We fight for the right of the underprivileged. That is what we will be doing in South Australia right up until the close of the polls on 6 November. I am quite happy and sure in my knowledge that, after that date, the underprivileged in South Australia will be looked after by a Premier, in the person of John Bannon, who will do justice to their cause and we will get back on the steady road to recovery in South Australia.

I wind up by saying that I have suffered very greatly today by being attired in this tie. It has been a great encumbrance to me. I have made my point. Tomorrow when we assemble I will be in my usual attire and the tie will rest in its place in the wardrobe until I have to bring it out again for the celebration of the MacLaren clan meeting about this time next year in Edinburgh. Who knows, I might even be there to enjoy again the vintage from McLaren Vale, which they purchase and have on the shelf in Edinburgh to drink the health of all the MacLarens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to say that the discomfort Senator McLaren suffered today from wearing that tie is as nothing to the discomfort he will suffer if I get my hands on him. I now understand why Senator McLaren does not wear a tie. Anyone with his habit of speaking so often in this place must know that it would be extremely dangerous to wear anything that would assist in strangling him. Having listened to Senator McLaren about his warlike clan, I venture to guess that, if Senator McLaren is a genuine example of that clan, members of the clan have talked their way into more trouble than they have ever fought their way out of. I also suggest that the current gathering taking place in Scotland will last for a very long time.

SPEECH.PARA: Three other matters were raised in the adjournment debate. Senator Foreman raised the matter of Kelvinator Australia Ltd and the concerns which he gave vent to in Question Time this morning about the possibility of loss of employment in that firm due to competition from imported air conditioners. That matter has been reported on by the Temporary Assistance Authority. The matter is being considered by the Government and his fellow South Australian, Senator Messner, has also been taking an active interest in the pursuit of that particular matter. I will ensure that the remarks of Senator Foreman are drawn to the attention of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Peacock).

Senator Bolkus raised a number of matters which showed a certain amount of concern about a Mr Alan Carroll. The main drift that I could get from the honourable senator was that he did not regard Mr Alan Carroll as a totally objective observer. I can only say, as he is concerned about people who appear on the Australian Broadcasting Commission as commentators, that I thought that in general people were selected to comment for the ABC because they had a point of view. One evening program seems particularly to use, for example, Marxist commentators on a regular basis. I note that Cooke, the man who provides letters from America, consistently provides comment which I would have thought showed a strong conservative bias. I note that in the Coming Out Ready or Not Show there seems to be a consistently feminist viewpoint and I have heard occasionally people like Professor Wheelwright who, I would not have thought, would speak without a strong doctrinal line. What Mr Carroll's views are I do not know. Quite frankly, I do not care. But I would have thought that it was a feature of the people who comment that they have a strong point of view. If, occasionally, that point of view is one which is biased in favour of private enterprise, I for one will not complain.

As to his connection with Roxby Downs, I have no knowledge of that but I would have thought that one would not need to be either biased or informed in detail to understand that Roxby Downs is the largest single opportunity that South Australia has for substantial economic development and I would have thought the considerable emphasis placed on that project by the present Government simply reflected the reality that, if a project of that size could be got off the ground, it would be of very substantial advantage to the State of South Australia.

The third matter of substance was raised by Senator Colston. I very quickly sought some information on the Maryborough Community Youth Support Scheme. He is quite right in saying that it is a matter which has received a lot of attention. The local member has been very involved in representation over a period of some months. I can advise that the project was recommended for closure by the Queensland CYSS committee in June of this year. It was recommended for closure on the ground that it was failing to meet the criteria for a basic CYSS project as set out under the guidelines and in particular there was inadequate participation and poor management. Honourable senators who remember the controversy over CYSS when it was proposed that it should be discontinued as a project generally will recall that there were significant complaints about ineffective CYSS projects. When it was decided that CYSS would be continued it was determined that there should be an effort to ensure that the projects were in fact effective. Apparently the Maryborough project, in the view of the CYSS State committee, was not effective; there was inadequate participation and poor management.

In the light of the representation received at that time by the relevant Minister, which was that the project could improve itself and become a viable project, a decision was taken by the Minister to give a further grant to the project. That started on 1 July 1982. The grant was made on the basis that the project would improve but that, if the State committee felt that the project was not improving and that the further grant was doing nothing to improve the situation, it should not hesitate to come back to him with a further recommendation. Soon after that, an officer of the Department visited Queensland to discuss the matter with the local committee and the local member. At any time during the course of any project's grant, the State committee can make a recommendation to the Minister that the project be closed providing that it believes that the pro- ject is not operating adequately. Apparently the State committee in this case was convinced that nothing was being done to improve the project and it felt obliged to come back with a further recommendation for closure. The project has already been given a period of grace but apparently that has not been used to good effect-hence the further recommendation for closure which has been accepted by the Minister. I am advised that the local member and the project itself have been informed.

I think at the heart of the matter raised by Senator Colston was his inquiry towards the end of his comments as to whether that was an irrevocable decision. I think history shows that every effort has been made to maintain this project. As to whether a further project would be entertained in the future, I would have to refer that question to the Minister. I am not sure whether current guidelines permit projects to be started up again. But I would say with some confidence that, if that possibility is open, it would be likely to be entertained only if there were such local support as would give a pretty clear indication that the deficiencies which apparently have dogged the project would not be a feature of any reopening. So, if there is concern about the failure of the CYSS project in Maryborough and the representations which have been made indicate that there is interest in having an effective project, clearly there will have to be adequate involvement in Maryborough itself to ensure that the guidelines for CYSS can be met and that the Commonwealth funds which are expended are used to good effect for the youth of that area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.30 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Which migration resource centres allow local community groups to use such offices as a postal address.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Migrant resource centres are autonomous organisations which are free to determine their own policy and management within the objectives set by the Government in establishing them.
None of these objectives impinge on a centre's authority to allow or disallow the use of its address as a postal address for other community groups.

The principle of self-determination of migrant resource centres has been underlined by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs in its Evaluation of Post-Arrival Programs and Services. It reaffirmed that migrant resource centres should be independent of government control. The Government has endorsed this proposal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will Australia bill the Iranian Government for the accommodation used by the Pakistani seamen who deserted an Iranian grain vessel recently in the port of Albany.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: On 30 August 1982 the vessel Iran Entekhab arrived in Australia at the port of Albany to load wheat destined for Iran.

On 7 September 1982 eleven Pakistani crew members disembarked from the vessel, sat on the wharf and refused to return to the vessel. The reason given for this action was that they had recently spent time in Iranian waters and had been subject to attack from forces involved in the Iran/Iraq conflict. They refused to accompany the vessel on its return to Iran because of fear for their personal safety.

The master of the vessel declared the men as deserters but at all times the shipping agents responsible were in control of the situation and kept the departments concerned fully abreast of developments.

The shipping agents made arrangements for the accommodation of the eleven crew members in Albany, flew them to Perth, arranged accommodation there and made further arrangements for the return of the crew members to Pakistan on 16 September 1982.

The assessment was that the crew members concerned were not going to abscond and accordingly the arrangements made by the shipping agents were allowed to proceed. The eleven crew members departed as per arrangements on 16 September 1982.
The Commonwealth did not incur any expenditure for the accommodation or air fares of the crew members concerned, these being met totally by the responsible shipping agents.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1294) Senator Martin asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is he aware of allegations that the development of tourist facilities on Heron Island could disturb the island's turtle rookery? Also, is he aware of the contents of environmental impact statement and management plan for the island? If so, will the contents of the EIS and the management plan be made available to the meeting of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority on Heron Island on 5 November? If the Minister does not know the contents of the EIS and the management plan would it be possible for the Government to obtain this information from P and O Australia Ltd, the developers of the Heron Island tourist complex?
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Heron Island is a Queensland owned island. Heron Island Pty Ltd, a subsidiary of P and O Australia, leases a portion of the island on which the resort is located.

The development of a tourist resort on Heron Island is the responsibility of the Queensland Government. Consequently, the need or otherwise for an environmental impact statement (EIS) in relation to the resort would also be a matter for the Queensland Government. I understand that no EIS was prepared for the State authorities prior to the commencement of recent extensions to the resort.

With regard to the management plan, I draw the honourable senator's attention to the fifth communique of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council, which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 14 September 1982 by the Minister for Science and Technology on my behalf. It stated that:

The Council agreed to the desirability of adopting complementary management regimes for this Section (of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park), and agreed that the matter should be reviewed further in the light of a pilot study in relation to Heron Island.

The Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service is currently preparing a management plan which focuses on the land aspects of Heron Island, including the protection and conservation of the island's turtle rookery. I am advised that the plan will be considered by the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council at a meeting next month and that the plan will be finalised after consultation with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.
